characters: DECK OF BARGE MOORED TO THE END OF THE PIER

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STERNWOOD PLACE
dialogues.text: It is a millionaire's house, big, sprawling, California style, with clipped lawns and gardens, on a hill above th now abandoned oil field which was the family's wealth. A small coupe drives up to the door and stops, and Philip Marlowe gets out. We just have time to establish him as h approaches the door -- a husky, self-confident man, well- dressed but not flashy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lettered

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: as NORRIS opens the door. Norris is thin, silver-haired with a gentle intelligent face.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (holding the door) Good morning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm Philip Marlowe. General Sternwood sent for me.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (opens door, steps aside) Yes, Mr. Marlowe. Will you come in?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (entering) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Norris shuts the door, takes Marlowe's hat.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Will you sit here? I'll tell the General you have come.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Okay. Norris exits. Marlowe looks about, interested and curiou sees something, moves toward it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: as he stands before a portrait, examining it with curious interest. It is a portrait of General Sternwood, in regimentals, beneath crossed battle-torn cavalry pennons and a sabre. He is still staring at the portrait when at SOUND OFF, he turns and sees CARMEN STERNWOOD approaching She is about 20, in slacks, something sullen and hot abou her. She stops about 10 feet from him and stares at him, biting the thumb of her left hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (after a moment) You're not very tall are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I tried to be.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Not bad looking, though -- you probably know it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks. He goes to a chair and sits down. When he looks up, he sees Carmen approaching, still staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (approaching) What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Reilly -- Doghouse Reilly.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (beside the chair now) That's a funny name. Are you a prize fighter?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. I'm a shamus.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: A private detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cute. As she speaks, she sits suddenly on the arm of his chair. As she does so, Marlowe rises, shifts the chair in doing so, so that to her surprise, Carmen finds herself sitting in the chair itself. She stares up, surprised and then angrily, is about to speak again when they both see Norri He has just entered noiselessly, stands beside the chair. On Norris' face there is now a curious expression of grie sadness. Carmen glances up at him, rises quickly as if he had reprimanded her with words, and exits. Marlowe looks after her, thoughtful, a little grim.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: The General will see you now.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (looking after Carmen) Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Miss Carmen Sternwood, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You ought to wean her. She looks old enough.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. This way, if you please. They exit through French doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garage at one side, beyond it a tremendous greenhouse. Norris is leading Marlowe along the path toward the green house. A chauffeur is washing a car before the garage. we establish him in passing -- a handsome, boyish-looking ma OWEN TAYLOR. Marlowe follows Norris on to the greenhouse, looking at t tremendous size of it as Norris opens the door and stands aside for Marlowe to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe, following Norris between the crowding tendrils a branches. The place is oven-hot, damp with sweat, green with gloom. Marlowe is already reacting to it, is already mopping his face with his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mopping neck, following Norris) Couldn't we have gone around this?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (over shoulder; walking on) The General sits in here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: in a wheelchair in center of the greenhouse, in a cleared space about which the plants crowd and hover. The GENERAL is the man we saw in the portrait, though older, and obviously dying, so that only his fierce eyes seem to hav any life. Even in the terrific heat his body is wrapped i a traveling rug and a heavy bathrobe, his gnarled hands lying like dead gnarled twigs on the rug, his fierce eyes following as Norris leads Marlowe in.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (stopping) This is Mr. Marlowe, General. The General does not speak, only the fierce eyes stare at Marlowe as Norris pushes a wicker chair up behind Marlowe legs.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Brandy, Norris. (to Marlowe) How do you like your brandy, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (sitting down) Just with brandy. Norris takes Marlowe's hat, exits.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: I used to like mine with champagne. The champagne cold as Valley Forge and about three ponies of brandy under it. You may take your coat off, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks. He rises, removes his coat, takes out his handkerchief, hangs his coat on chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching him) It's too hot in here for any man who still has blood in his veins. Marlowe sits again, mops his face and neck.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (still watching him) You may smoke too. I can still enjoy the smell of it, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks. He produces a Cigarette, lights it, blows smoke, Sternwoo nostrils moving as he sniffs the smoke. Norris enters, pushing a teawagon bearing decanter, siphon, initialed ice-bucket.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: That man is already dead who must indulge his own vices by proxy. Norris wheels the wagon up, starts to prepare a drink.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (watching pettishly) Come, man. Pour a decent one.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (adding brandy) Yes, General.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (watching) But not too decent, Norris. I don't want to exchange places with it. Norris adds soda, hands glass to Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (taking glass) Thanks. He sits back. Norris covers the ice-bucket with a napkin, exits. SOUND of DOOR CLOSING as Norris leaves the greenhouse. Marlowe raises the glass, sips. Sternwood watches him, licks his lips with longing pleasure and enjoyment. Marlowe lowers the glass.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Tell me about yourself, Mr. Marlowe. I suppose I have the right to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not much to tell. I'm thirty-eight years old, went to college once. I can still speak English when there's any demand for it in my business. I worked for the District Attorney's office once. It was Bernie Ohls, his chief investigator, who sent me word you wanted to see me. I'm not married.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: You didn't like working for Mr. Wilde?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I was fired for insubordination I seem to rate pretty high on that.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: I always did, myself. Sir -- (he slides one hand under the rug on his knees) What do you know about my family, Mr. Marlowe?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (mopping ) oo. . You're a widower, a millionaire, two young daughters. One unmarried, the other married once but it didn't didn't take. Both now living with you and both -- (he breaks off; the General's fierce eyes watch him)

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Am I to swap you gossip for hospitality?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (sternly) You are to swap me your confidence for my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) All right. Both pretty, and both pretty -- wild. What did you want to see me about?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: I'm being blackmailed again.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: __ (mopping) Again?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (draws his hand out from under the rug, holding a brown envelope) About a year ago I paid a man named Joe Brody five thousand dollars to let my younger daughter alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It means 'ah.' It never went through the D.A.'s office, or I'd have known it. Who handled that for you?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Shawn Regan did.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (alternating between the drink, the cigarette and the now sodden handkerchief with which he mops his face and neck) There must be some reason why Regan's not handling this one too. Am I to know it?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Shawn has left me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I hadn't seen him around lately.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Yes, he left about a month ago, without a word. That was what hurt. I had no claim on him, since I was only his employer. But I hoped we were more than that and that he would have said goodbye to me. You knew him too?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes. From the old days, when he was running rum from Mexico and I was on the other side, and now and then we swapped shots between drinks -- or drinks between shots, if you like that better.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: My respects to you. Few men ever exchange more than one shot with Shawn Regan. He commanded a brigade in the Irish Republican Army, you know.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (moppin No, I didn't. But I knew he was a good man at whatever he did. Nobody was pleased better than me when I heard you had taken him on as your -- whatever he was here.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: As my friend, my son almost. Many's the hour he would sit here with me, sweating like a pig, drinking the brandy I could no longer drink, telling me stories of the Irish revolution -- But enough of this. (he holds out the envelope) Here. And help yourself to the brandy. Marlowe takes the envelope, sits again, wipes his hands o his wet handkerchief, removes from the envelope a card an three clips of stiff paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- in Marlowe's hand Mr. Arthur Gwynne Geiger Rare Books and Deluxe Editions Marlowe's hand turns the card over. On the back, in hand-printing. Dear Sir: In spite of the legal uncollectibility of the enclosed, which frankly are gambling debts, I assume you might wish them honored. Respectfully, A.G. Geiger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Filled out in ink, dated: September 3 September 8 September 11 On demand I promise to pay to Arthur Gwynne Geiger on order the sum of One Thousand Dollars ($1,000.00) without interest. Value Received. Carmen Sternwood

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD AND MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sternwood watching from wheelchair as Marlowe mixes himse a drink at the wagon, then turns toward chair.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (watching Marlowe) well?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (standing) Who's Arthur Gwynne Geiger?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: I haven't the faintest idea.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Have you asked your daughter?  10.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: I don't intend to. If I did she would suck her thumb and look coy.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I met her in the hall. She did that at me. Then she tried to sit in my lap. Sternwood stares at him. After a moment Marlowe raises th glass, drinks, lowers it.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (harshly) well?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (stares at him a moment) Am I being polite, or can I say what I want?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Do the two girls run around together?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: I think not. They are alike only in their one corrupt blood. Vivian is spoiled, exacting, smart, ruthless. Carmen is still the child who likes to pull the wings off flies. I assume they have always had all the usual vices; whatever new ones of their own invention -- (again he makes the repressed convulsive movement, glares at Marlowe) well?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Pay him.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Why?  11.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It's cheaper. A little money against a lot of annoyance. The money you won't miss, and if your heart hasn't broken long before this time, whatever's behind these -- (indicates the notes on the chair) -- can't do it now.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Not my heart. No Sternwood ever had one. But there is my pride, which I at least, and I believe my older daughter still, both have.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure. A man named A.G. Geiger's just betting himself three thousand bucks on that pride. Who was this Joe Brody you paid the five thousand to?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: I don't recall. Norris would know. My butler. I think he called himself a gambler. (hopefully) This may be an authentic gambling debt, after all. Marlowe looks at Sternwood for a moment. Then he half turns, sets the glass on the wagon and takes the napkin from around the ice bucket and mops himself with it. Sternwood watches him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (after a second) No. Marlowe mops himself again with the napkin, puts it back the wagon, takes up his glass, drinks.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I guess you want me to take this Geiger off your back: that right?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Do you want to know anything, or do you just want to be rid of him?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Didn't you just tell me I no longer have any heart to be broken?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It may cost you a little -- besides my own twenty-five a day and expenses. Sternwood says nothing, merely makes a faint, impatient movement of his head or shoulders. Marlowe drains the glass, sets it back on the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: When do I start?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: At once. And now if you will excuse me -- But another brandy before you go?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (takes up papers from chair, then his coat) No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (presses bell plugged into chair arm) Then good morning. And good luck. He lies back in the chair, closes his eyes. Marlowe watches him a moment, then, his coat over his arm and sti mopping his neck, he turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: emerges, still carrying his coat, dripping wet, mopping with his sodden handkerchief, breathing the cool air, starts away. Before he reaches the house, Norris meets him, pauses two feet away, silver-haired, respectful, grave.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Rutledge, the older daughter would like to see you before you leave, sir. And about the money: the General has instructed me to give you a check for whatever you require.  13. 13.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Instructed you how?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (blinks, stares, then smiles) Ah, I see, sir. I forgot you are a detective. By the way he rang the bell.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You write his checks.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: I have that privilege.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (starts on) That ought to save you from a pauper's grave. I won't need any money now, thanks -- How did Mrs. Rutledge know I was here?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: She saw you through the window. I was obliged to tell her who you were.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I don't like that.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Are you attempting to tell me my duties, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. Just having fun trying to guess what they are.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: This way, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is large, over-elaborate, feminine. VIVIAN reclines on a chaise-lounge, showing her legs to good advantage. She is beautiful, giving an impression of strong will and strong emotions, the dangerous unpredictable type.  14. She sips a drink, insolently at ease, watching Marlowe as he enters. Marlowe is still rumpled and sweating. He adopts her be-damned-to-you attitude, looks her over, and sits down unbidden, wiping his face and neck with his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: So you're a private detective. I didn't know they existed except in books, or else they were little greedy men snooping around hotels. My, you're a mess, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I'm not the orchid-bearing type.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: This business of Dad's -- think you can handle it for him?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (sardonically) It doesn't look too tough.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Really. I would have thought a case like that took a little effort.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not too much.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Well! what will your first step be?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The usual one.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I didn't know there was a usual one.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. It comes complete with diagrams on Page forty-seven of "How to be a Detective in Ten Easy Lessons", correspondence school textbook.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You must have read another one on how to be a comedian. I'm quite serious, Mr. Marlowe. My father is not well, and I want this case handled with the least possible worry to him.  15.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's the way I'm going to handle it.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I see. No professional secrets. Marlowe doesn't answer. He's still admiring her legs. Vivian sets her glass down, looking him over coolly, as though he were something in a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: How do you like Dad?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I liked him.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: He liked Shawn. I suppose you know who Shawn is?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You don't have to play poker with me. Dad wants to find him, doesn't he?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Of course I do! It wasn't right for him to go off like that. Broke Dad's heart, although he won't say much about it. Or did he?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I don't see what there is to be cagey about. And I don't like your manners.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm not crazy about yours. I didn't ask to see you. And I don't mind your ritzing me, or drinking your lunch out of a bottle. I don't mind your showing me your legs. They're very swell legs and it's a pleasure to make their acquaintance. I don't mind if you don't like my manners. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're pretty bad. I grieve over them during the long winter evenings. But don't waste your time trying to cross-examine me. Vivian is really angry now. She swings her legs to the floor, and her anger is something sparkling and terrific.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: People don't talk like that to me. Marlowe laughs at her softly. His eyes are warm and mocking. Vivian relaxes slowly, looking at him, and something besides fury comes into her own face.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Do you always think you can handle people like trained seals?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Just what is it you're afraid of? They watch each other, and Vivian's face closes against him like a door.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Dad didn't want to see you about Shawn at all.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Get out. (as Marlowe rises and turns from her) Please... you could find Shawn if Dad wanted you to.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (still dead pan) When did he go?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: A month back. He just drove away one afternoon without saying a word. They found his car in some private garage.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (her manner suddenly different, as though she has won her bout with him) Dad didn't tell you then.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He told me about Regan, yes. That's not what he wanted to see me about. Is that what you've been trying to get me to say?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I'm sure I don't care what you say.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (giving her a look she could chin herself on) You might change your mind about that some day. So long, Mrs. Rutledge. Vivian watches him as he goes out, with smoldering, puzzled eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe comes down the hall, heading for the door. Norris appears with Marlowe's hat and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You made a mistake. Mrs. Rutledge didn't want to see me.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. I make many mistakes. He opens the door. Marlowe pauses to look at the view.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: Beyond the lawns and hedges of the Sternwood estate the ground falls away to barren fields with several old woode derricks, some of them still wearily pumping oil. The derricks are at a considerable distance from the house, b a man with binoculars could see any activity around them clearly enough. The sky is clouded; THUNDER SOUNDS distantly.  18.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How long those wells been pumping?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: About thirty years. The General likes to take his field glasses sometimes and sit by the window and watch the walking-beams. They're like life, he says -- an endless seesaw, forever up and down and getting nowhere

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: They get oil. Black stuff, with a smell to it... worth dollars. He goes out, gets into his car and drives away. The SOUND of THUNDER follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The typical reading room, with the usual characters hunch over books at the tables. Marlowe stands by the librarian's desk. A boy comes from the door to the stacks and hands the librarian a book. She looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: Famous First Editions. (looking at Marlowe -- it is obvious that she feels he's not the type to be reading about first editions) This was the one you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (blandly, as he takes the book) I collect blondes, too -- in bottles. He walks over to a table and sits down, leaving the woman staring after him.  19. 20. 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign on window: "RARE EDITIONS" etc. Marlowe walks up and pauses to assure himself that it's the right place. The store front is narrow. Discreet gold lettering on the plate glass repeats the legend on Geiger's card:

dialogues.speaker: A.G. GEIGER
dialogues.text: Rare Books and Deluxe Editions The windows are blanked off with Chinese screens, fronted by large Oriental urns. Marlowe puts on a pair of horn- rimmed sun glasses, adjusts his hat to a less rakish angle, and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is small, din, expensively underfurnished with leather chairs, smoking stands, and a small psuedo- Oriental desk. A few sets of tooled leather binds on narrow tables, others in glass cases. AGNES, a hard-looking, expensive blonde in a tight black dress, rises from behind the desk as Marlowe approaches and moves to greet him. Her manner is professionally distant, her accent betrays her phony veneer.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Can I be of any assistance?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Would you happen to have a Ben Hur 1860?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (hanging on hard to her composure, seeing that she's going to have trouble with Marlowe) A first edition?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. Third -- the one with the erratum on page one-sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not -- at the moment.  20.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How about a Chevalier Audubon -- the full set of course?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (with a frozen smile) Uh -- not at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (politely) You do sell books?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (dropping the act, pointing to the display books) What do those look like -- grapefruit?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: They look like books from here, anyway. Maybe I'd better talk to Mr. Geiger.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: He's not in at the moment. Marlowe glances up as a man enters the store; a middle- aged, important-looking person who has an incongruously furtive and nervous manner. He looks quickly at Marlowe, then at Agnes, who gives him an almost imperceptible warning nod. Marlowe remains blandly unaware of the byplay, all his attention apparently on the cigarette he' lighting. The man walks quickly to the rear of the store. Agnes pushes a button on the desk. A door in the back wall open on a buzzer lock. The man darts through it like a rabbit.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (to Marlowe) I said Mr. Geiger is not in.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I heard you. I'll wait for him.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: He won't be back until very late. At this point the furtive man comes out of the rear part the store and leaves hurriedly, looking at neither Agnes nor Marlowe. His face is lined and haggard. Marlowe is interested.  21. 21.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (watching the man out) He must have got hold of the wrong title. (to Agnes) Well, guess I'd better blow. I'm already late now for my lecture on Argentine cera-micks. (mispronouncing the word)

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (icily, correcting him) The word is cerAMics. And they ain't Argentine: they're Egyptian.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You did sell a book once, didn't you? Well, even the Argentine's a little too far for me today. Guess I'll just stick to the public library -- or I might try that book store across the street.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (freezing) Do so. Agnes stares viciously at his back until he is out. Then she goes to the door at the rear, knocks and goes through

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He walks across the boulevard, turns into a small bookstore, the second-hand variety, cluttered and dingy. Several nondescript people browse among the tables. At th rear a small, dark, shrewd-faced woman sits reading at a desk -- apparently she is the proprietor. Marlowe approaches her, and she looks up blank-faced from her boo

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Would you do me a very small favor?

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: I don't know. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You know Geiger's store across the street?

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: I think I may have passed it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You know Geiger by sight?  The woman open it. The woman 22.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: I should think it would be easy enough to go to his store and ask to see him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I don't want to see him that close, just yet. (as he gets no response) Know anything about rare books?

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: You could try me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Would you have a Ben Hur, 1860, Third Edition, with the duplicated line on page one-sixteen? pulls a fat volume in front of her, starts to

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: ...or a Chevalier Audubon 1840...? stops, closes the book.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: Nobody would. There isn't one.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Right. (as the woman gives him a puzzled stare) The girl in Geiger's store didn't know that.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: I see. You begin to interest me -- vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm a private dick on a case. Perhaps I ask too much. (leaning forward to hold a match for her cigarette) It didn't seem much to me somehow.  22. 23.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: (after a pause) In his early forties, medium height, fattish, soft all over, a Charlie Chan moustache. Well dressed, goes without a hat, affects a knowledge of antiques and hasn't any. Oh yes, his left eye is glass.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You'd make a good cop.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: (returning to her reading) Only if he wore smoked glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (laughing softly -- pulling a flat pint from his hip pocket) I shouldn't think you'd have to work too hard to start anything smoking. He shakes the bottle up and down, invitingly. She looks u at him, searchingly, then smiles slowly.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: It's going to rain, soon.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'd rather get wet in here. She pulls open a drawer and stands two small glasses on the desk. Marlowe smiles, and starts pouring. Through the window behind him the front of Geiger's store can be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining hard outside. The proprietress is a little tight, quite relaxed, and slightly philosophical, leaning against Marlowe, who sits on a stack of Britannicas besid her, watching the window. The proprietress picks up the bottle, which is now empty, shakes it forlornly, and sets it down again.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: A couple of hours, an empty bottle, and so long, pal. That's life.  24.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: But it was a nice two hours.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: (sighing) Uh-huh. (looking toward the window) There's Geiger's car driving up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (over above action) Who's the other guy?

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: Damon -- or Pythias. I don't know. Geiger's shadow, anyway. Name's Carol Lundgren. Marlowe has risen, is now in a hurry to follow Geiger.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So long, pal.

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: If you ever want to buy a book...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: A Ben Bur eighteen-sixty...

dialogues.speaker: PROPRIETRESS
dialogues.text: (sighing) With duplications... So long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wet with rain:

dialogues.speaker: TERRACE
dialogues.text: A narrow street with a high bank on one side and a scattering of cabinlike houses built down the slope on th other side, so that their roofs are not much above street level. They are masked by hedges and shrubs. Sodden trees line the dark road.  25. 26. 27. 28. 25. The headlights of a car appear. Geiger's coupe drives up and stops in front of the garage of a small house almost completely hidden by a square box hedge. Geiger gets out, opens an umbrella, and vanishes behind the hedge. Almost immediately Marlowe's car appears, continuing slowly past Geiger's house. It turns, stops under a tree. The lights go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe yawns, gets a bottle out of the dash compartment, shakes it reflectively.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Another hour, another bottle -- another dame? He uncaps the bottle, salutes an unseen person wryly, drinks, then lights a cigarette and settles down to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark convertible stops in front of Geiger's house. The lights go out. A small slim woman in a vagabond hat and raincoat gets out. She pauses, looking around -- we see her face dimly. It is CARMEN STERNWOOD. She vanishes behind the hedge. The DOORBELL RINGS faintly, the door opens and closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe looks offscene after Carmen, with an unpleasant grin.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- another dame. His expression indicates that things may pick up shortly. He looks at his watch -- the CAMERA MOVES IN to feature t watch -- the hands standing at 6:35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hands now indicate: 7:20  29. 30. 31. 32. 33. 34. 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING obliquely across Marlowe's shoulder, showing the street and particularly Geiger's house through the rain- streaked windscreen. Suddenly a hard white flash of light shoots out of Geiger's house like s flash of lightning. Close on its heels comes a woman's thin half-pleasurable scream. Marlowe is out of the car and on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe rounds the hedge on the run. There is a wooden footbridge bridging the gap between the bank and the fron door. He covers this in two jumps and stops at the front door. The knocker is in the shape of a lion's head, and ring in its mouth. Marlowe puts his hand on it, and as he does, three SHOTS SOUND from inside. Marlowe freezes. From inside we HEAR a sighing groan and the thud of a falling body, then footsteps going away. Marlowe looks over the railing of the bridge, but there's no way around to the back. He stands still, listening. Light shows from the house, behind draperies. From offscene at some distance, we HEAR someone running down steps.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (RAIN)
dialogues.text: On a man's feet, running with hysterical speed down the w treads. We follow them across muddy ground, apparently a dirt road surface, to a car.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY BELOW GEIGER'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: As a car starts and roars away with clashing gears. Almos before it is out of sight a second car pulls out from und shrouding trees and follows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the two cars is still audible, fading into distance. Marlowe listens to it. When everything is quiet again he tries the front door, finds it locked. French windows flank the door just out of reach beyond the raili of the bridge. Marlowe swings out over the railing, kicks in the right-hand window, and pulls himself over the sill

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Marlowe comes in through the window. The room is wide, low-beamed ceiling, brown plaster walls with strips of Chinese embroidery and Oriental prints on them. Low bookshelves, a desk, thick rug floor cushions, low divans -- an exotic messy atmosphere.  27. On a low dais at one end of the room is a carved teakwood chair, a massive thing in which Carmen Sternwood sits, rigidly erect, in the pose of an Egyptian goddess. She wears a man's large silk dressing gown -- it doesn't pretend to fit her and gives the impression of having bee thrown hurriedly around her by someone other than herself Carmen's eyes have a queer fixed stare. She pays no attention to Marlowe. She looks as if, in her mind, she i doing something very important and doing it well. She seems pleased about it, her lips curved to a smile. She laughs from time to time -- softly, secretly. Opposite her, Geiger lies on the floor in front of a thin like a totem pole. The eye of the totem is a camera lens; it focuses on the chair where Carmen sits. A blackened flash bulb is clipped to the totem beside it. Geiger is dressed in semi-oriental fashion. His embroidered coat is soaked with blood. He is obviously dead. Marlowe takes all this in, sniffs the air. It is heavy with something unpleasant. He crosses to a small lacquer table bearing a flagon of dark liquid and two glasses. Marlowe sniffs the flagon, makes a grimace of disgust. Carmen's clothes are wadded up on the divan. Marlowe pick up her coat and shoes and goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hello. Remember me. She doesn't seem to see him. The soft, secret laughter is his only answer. He goes closer, and deliberately slaps her face. This gets a reaction -- he slaps her again, without emotion, but hard. Carmen comes to, slightly, giving him a sly, mad smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're higher than a kite. Come on, let's be nice. Let's get dressed, Carmen. He puts her shoes on.

dialogues.speaker: ___ CARMEN
dialogues.text: (giggling) You tickle.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you tickle me, too. Marlowe pulls her to her feet and puts her coat on, tryin not to dislodge the dressing gown. She falls against him, very happy about it all, apparently about to pass out. Marlowe is not happy.  35. 36. 28.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Let's take a walk.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (thickly, half conscious) You're cute.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure, sure. So's your boyfriend. Want to look at him? He walks the staggering girl over to Geiger's body. It is hard work -- and Carmen is not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (as before) He's cute.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Cute. Yeah. Let's walk. He walks her back and forth across the room a couple of times -- LOW CAMERA FEATURING the dead man as their legs pass in front of him. Then she passes out in his arms, still convinced that everything is cute. He spreads her out on the divan, unconsciously wiping his hands on his coat as though he has touched something dirty. Then he returns to the totem and Geiger's body. He examines the concealed camera. The plateholder is gone. He rolls Geiger's body over enough to see under it. No plateholder. He frowns thoughtfully at the girl... then goes into the rear of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe passes quickly through the bath and kitchen, pausing to try the locked kitchen door and to examine a window which had been jimmied open. The scars show plainl on the wood, the rain blowing in unheeded. Marlowe then goes to the bedroom, which is in keeping with the living room. He glances briefly through the closet, with a man's clothes in it, then picks up a keyholder from the dressin table, where it has been placed along with other contents of Geiger's pockets -- money, handkerchief, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe returns and unlocks the desk. In one drawer he finds a locked steel box, which he opens with Geiger's keys. He takes from it a leather book.  37. 38. 39. 40. 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leafs through the pages slowly, showing an index and writing in code, in the same slanted printing as on the cards General Sternwood gave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe places the book in his pocket, wipes his fingerprints carefully from the box, replaces it end lock the desk. He pockets the keys, turns off the lamps and th gas logs in the fireplace, makes a wadded bundle of Carmen's clothes, jams her hat on her head and picks her up, holding her clothes awkwardly in one hand. On the way out he pushes down the light switch by the door, and kick the door shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe carries the sleeping girl out to her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe has just rung the doorbell. In the drive behind him stands Carmen's Packard. The door opens. Norris appears in it, recognizes Marlowe, looks swiftly past him and recognizes the car also. Then he looks at Marlowe again -- the same quiet, grave face with its expression of grief and sadness which the sight of the ca brought into it. His voice though is quiet and calm.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Good evening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (rapidly) Mrs. Rutledge in?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The General?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: He's asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Good. Where's Mrs. Rutledge's maid?  41. 30.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Mathilda? She's here.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Better get her down here. This job needs a woman's touch. Take a look inside the car. But Norris does not move, only his eyes go again to the waiting car and return, his face still grave, only the grief a little sharper behind it.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (quickly) She's all right?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure. She's okay. Just get that maid. Mathilda can do all right for her.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: We all try to do our best for her. I'll call Mathilda at once.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (turning) Then I'll leave it with you. Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: May I call you a cab, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (pauses) No. In fact, I'm not here. You haven't even seen me tonight -- see?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Marlowe turns on, fast, walking down the drive in the rai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe, a shadowy figure, enters, closes door behind him crosses the room to a lamp, turns the switch. Marlowe is quite wet, indicating that he has walked back from Sternwood's.  42. 43. 44. 31. He stands with his hand still on the light switch, looks about the room, crosses to another tamp, puts it on, is about to turn away when he stops dead, reacts as he looks at the totem pole and at the floor beneath it where Geiger's body had lain. The body is gone. Marlowe crosses the room, wasting no time, determined. He passes through door to bedroom, snap light on beyond it, after a moment the light beyond the door snaps off and Marlowe re-enters living room. He has not found the body. He stands for a moment, thinking, the he goes and kneels so that he can squint along the surfac of the thick rug. He sees in the nap the marks where Geiger's heels were dragged along it, across the room toward the front door. He rises at last, thoughtful, slowly takes out a cigarette and lights it, drops match into ashtray, stops, takes up the dead match and puts it into his pocket. Then he takes out his handkerchief, goes and wipes off th bedroom doorknob, goes to the first lamp, turns it out an wipes it off, leaving room in darkness and himself a shad which can be barely seen in the act of wiping off that button. Then he crosses the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe as he closes and locks it, wipes off knob, pocket keys, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe, sitting at a table, the code book which he found at Geiger's open before him, a highball at his hand as he tries to work out the code. He cannot solve it. His hand reaches for the highball glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe, in bed, wakes reluctantly as LOUD KNOCKING on th apartment door penetrates his slumber. He crawls out of bed, obviously the worse for a hangover, pulls ona dressing gown as he staggers sleepily toward the next roo

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (as the KNOCKING continues) All right, all right. Keep your pants on...  45. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe opens it to admit BERNIE OHLS, a dapper slightly flashy man, whose clothes are expensive and alwa a little wrong. His face is dapper and deceiving since it is actually the face of a man who has been in close place in the course of his duty, has killed several lawbreakers at times when he was outnumbered and they thought he was covered and helpless until too late. He is pleasant and affable to all, respects courage, loves no man.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Well Bernie. Don't you ever go to bed?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (entering -- surveying Marlowe) Boy, what a beautiful hangover! Tut, tut -- man your age, out on the town all night...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I got it right here.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (sitting) That's even worse.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: All right -- what is it?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Does it have to be something?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Look, Bernie, when somebody from the Homicide Squad comes over to help...

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: You're working for the Sternwoods, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (warily) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Done anything for ‘em yet?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How could I do anything yesterday in all that rain?  46. 33.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (laughing) Okay -- They seem to be a family that things happen to. A big Buick belonging to one of them is washing around in the surf off Lido fish pier. Oh yea, I almost forgot. There's a guy in it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (flatly, after a pause) Regan?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Who? Oh, you mean that Irish ex-legger old Sternwood hired to do his drinking for him. What would he be doing down there? He watches Marlowe's face narrowly -- it tells him nothin

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What would anybody be doing down there?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: That's what I'm going to Lido to find out. Want to come?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks, Bernie. Yeah, be with you in ten minutes. He starts out, already pulling off his dressing gown. Ohls looks after him, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohls is driving. It is an official car, now and then Ohls sounds the siren.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: It ain't Regan. I checked up. Regan's a big guy, tall as you and a shade heavier. This is a young kid. (he SOUNDS SIREN -- the car is going fast) What made you think it was Regan?  34.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Who is it? Don't they know yet?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Now, now. Behave. What made Regan skip out? Or ain't you interested in that either?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why should I be?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: That wasn't what old Sternwood wanted you for, then?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Can't a guy quit a job anymore without notifying the District Attorney?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: When an ex-bootlegger gets himself hired into a job where all he's got to do is sit in a greenhouse and drink a millionaire's brandy, when he throws that job up --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm not looking for Regan.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Okay, keep buttoned, kid.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: General Sternwood told you to send me out to see him. But he never told me I was to report --

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: I said, keep it buttoned, didn't I? (SOUNDS SIREN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, you got to eat too -- even if I don't know why.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I don't know either. Ohls SOUNDS the SIREN AGAIN. The car speeds on.  47. 48. 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A faded stucco arch, the sea beyond it, the pier stretchi away as Ohls' car stops before the entrance and Ohls and Marlowe get out. Beside the arch are parked a police car and several police motorcycles. The long pier, railed wit white two-by-fours, runs out over the water. There are several private cars parked along the road, a crowd of people is gathered at the far end of the pier as a motorcycle officer, stationed beneath the arch, is holdin back another crowd as Ohls and Marlowe come up. Ohls show the officer his badge.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (to guard) Medical examiner come yet?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: (checks pass, waves them on) Beat you by 15 minutes. He's examining the guy now probably.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (pockets his pass) Oh, he is, huh? Didn't you guys ever hear of the D.A.'s office?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Keep your shirt on. There's a deputy in charge. Ohls, followed by Marlowe, passes onto the pier.

dialogues.speaker: SEAWARD END OF PIER
dialogues.text: A shattered gap in the railing at the end of the pier sho where the car crashed through. Another crowd of people held back by other policemen, gather along the broken railing in b.g. Beyond them, moored to the end of the pier, lies a flat barge with wheelhouse and derrick. As Ohls and Marlowe approach, the police herd the crowd back and four men come up from the barge, carrying a sheet-covered stretcher and carry it on across the SHOT - the crowd gaping after it. As the bearers are about to pass, Ohls stops them.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. The bearers stop. Ohls turns the sheet back, looks at the dead man's face.  49. 36.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder to Marlowe) Want a look? Marlowe looks at the face for a moment. Ohls drops the sheet back.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (to bearers) All right. Beat it. The bearers go on. Ohls and Marlowe approach the barge, the crowd gawking about them, after the stretcher, the policemen shoving among them.

dialogues.speaker: A POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (to crowd) That's all now. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: DECK OF BARGE MOORED TO THE END OF THE PIER
dialogues.text: On it sits the car which has been lifted from the water. It is the same black sedan which Marlowe saw the chauffeu washing yesterday in Sternwood's garage -- bent and stain with water. In front of the car are gathered Ohls, Marlowe, a uniformed deputy, two plainclothesmen and the Medical Examiner who has just finished repacking his smal black bag.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (to deputy) What's the story?

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: You can see most of it from here. Went through the rail yonder. Must have hit it pretty hard. The rain stopped down here about nine P.M. The broken ends of the rails are dry inside. That would put it about nine-thirty last night.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Drunk, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PLAINCLOTHESMAN
dialogues.text: Then he must have been that guy you hear about that always drives better drunk. He plowed an awful straight furrow down that pier, right to the end of it. Then he hit the railing right square head-on -- hard and clean -- or he wouldn't have gone through it.  50. They EXT. They hang 37.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: All right. Suicide then.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY
dialogues.text: The hand-throttle was set half-way down. Something had hit him a pretty hard lick across the left temple.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (to Medical Examiner ) All right, Doc. Let's have it.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: His neck was broken.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: What made the bruise? Steering-wheel?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL EXAMINER
dialogues.text: It was made by something covered. The wound had already bled under the skin while he was still alive.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: A blackjack? all turn and glance at Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (after a moment) I'd forgotten about you. Let's go back to town.

dialogues.speaker: PIER
dialogues.text: are walking back toward their car. A few people still around, staring at the barge.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: So you recognized him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sternwood's chauffeur. I saw him washing that same car yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: So that was what old Sternwood wanted with you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Look, I don't even know his name --  51. 38.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: I do. His name's Owen Taylor About a year or so back he run Sternwood's daughter, the hotcha one, off to Yuma. The older sister run after them and brought the girl back and had Taylor thrown into the icebox. Then the next day she comes down and begs the kid off -- said the kid meant to marry the sister only the sister can't see it. So they let the kid go, and darned if the Sternwoods don't have him come back to work, same as if nothing had happened.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And now somebody'll have to go see them about this.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Yep. That's me, probably.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Leave the old man out of it, if you can. He's got enough troubles already besides being sick.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Regan, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I don't know anything about Regan. I told you that.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Then what are you doing in this?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm not looking for Regan. I can tell you that much.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (dryly) . . Yeah. I heard you the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe enters, wearing the dark glasses as before, and a before, Agnes rises from behind the desk. She is not happ to see Marlowe.  39.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (cheerily) Hello -- I'm back again. Mr. Geiger in?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not. No. Marlowe glances around to make sure they're alone, then removes the glasses and moves close to Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It was just a stall about those first editions. I got something to sell. Something Geiger's wanted for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Oh -- I see. Well -- you might come back tomorrow. I think...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Drop the veil, sister. I'm in the business too. Agnes stares at him, scared stiff, not knowing how to get rid of him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (impatiently) I haven't got forever. Is he sick? I could go up to the house

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (frantically) No, that wouldn't do any good -- he's out of town. Couldn't you tomorrow? -- Marlowe glances up sharply as Carol Lundgren, the dark handsome boy in the leather jacket, opens the door in the rear wall. Behind him, through the open door, we see the back room, littered with the papers and boxes of hurried packing, and a gaunt, hard-looking man with a certain animal attractiveness in the midst of it, cramming folios and stacks of large-sized envelopes into the packing boxe Carol is obviously strained and under tension, looking as though he has not slept.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (desperately) Agnes, you've got to --  52. 53. 40. He becomes aware of Marlowe, shuts up abruptly, and slams the door. From the partition his voice rises, sharp but unintelligible, answered by a heavier, man's voice -- no words come through, but the implication is clearly that Carol shall shut up and get out. A door slams violently, then there is silence. Marlowe, ignoring this byplay, and the stricken look on Agnes' face, puts on his glasses and touches his hat.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, then. Early.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Yes, early. Before Marlowe has quite left the shop she darts back through the rear door.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: As he walks rapidly along the Boulevard to a taxi standin at the curb. A smart, competent-appearing girl sits reading a pulp magazine behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe sticks his head in, does a take, and relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (disgustedly) I would have to pick a girl at this point.

dialogues.speaker: CABBY
dialogues.text: (giving him a cold stare) Anything you want, bud, I can give you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (grinning) And with both fists, too, I'll bet. Tail job?

dialogues.speaker: CABBY
dialogues.text: Cop?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Private.

dialogues.speaker: CABBY
dialogues.text: (laying aside the magazine) Hop in. Marlowe looks down at the magazine.  54. 55. 56. 57. 58. 59. 60. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a copy of TWO-GUN DETECTIVE TALES, with a lurid cov of gunmen and a gory corpse.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (grinning) Okay, kid. Take it. He gets in quickly.

dialogues.speaker: CABBY
dialogues.text: (slapping down the flag) I got it. EXT. HOLLYWOOD STREET - CAB IN F.G. A light panel pickup job comes out of an alley and turns down the street. The gaunt, hard-looking man is driving. Marlowe leans forward and gives the cabby the high sign. The cab pulls out to follow.

dialogues.speaker: ESTABLISHING
dialogues.text: A section of Randall Place, featuring an apartment buildi with a basement garage. An awning stretches out over the sidewalk -- lettering along the awning's side reads, RANDALL ARMS. The panel truck drives past the entrance an turns into the basement garage. Some distance behind it w see the cab pull into the curb. Marlowe gets out and walk toward the RANDALL ARMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door stands open onto a small foyer, without desk or switchboard. A panel of gilt mailboxes is let into one wall of the entrance. Marlowe, after a glance inside, examines the names under the mail drops. One in particula catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name JOE BRODY is typewritten on the card.  61. 62. 63. 64. 65. 66. 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe taps the card, then gives the foyer one more Meaning look, turns.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RANDALL PLACE
dialogues.text: As Marlowe returns to it. He speaks to the girl, who nods and drives away with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the cab pulls into the curb in front of a non-descript office building. Marlowe gets out and leans in to pay the driver.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (handing her a bill) Nice going, kid. Buy yourself an orchid.

dialogues.speaker: CABBY
dialogues.text: Thanks. You can take my number in case you have any more jobs you want done right. (indicating the serial number on her driver's cap) I mean this number.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What number did you think I thought you meant? The Cabby flustered clashes the gears savagely, shoots th cab away. Marlowe tips his hat to her and enters the building as she drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe opens the door, which has Philip Marlowe in gilt letters on the upper glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room, cheaply furnished, with a closed door in on wall. Vivian sits waiting for him, beautifully but simply dressed, quite at ease. She seems in a better humor this Morning, smiling at the surprised Marlowe.  43.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Well, you DO exist, after all. I'd begun to think I dreamed you out of a bottle of bad gin. (with underlying hint of seriousness) I've been trying to get you on the phone all morning.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You can insult me just as well face to face. I don't bite -- much.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (apologetically) I was rather rude.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (smiling) An apology from a Sternwood? (unlocking the connecting door, holding it for her) Come into my boudoir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the waiting room, it's shabby and not large. The usual desk, chairs, and filing cabinets.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (sitting) You don't put on much of a front.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You can't make much money at this trade, if you're honest. If you have a front, you're making money or expect to.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Oh -- are you honest?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Painfully.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (taking out a cigarette) How did you get into this slimy business, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving her a look as he lights it for her) Because people like you pay good money to have the slime cleaned up. 44. She looks away from him, angry hut not able to say anything. Marlowe sits down behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What did you want to see me about? Taylor?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (softly) Poor Owen. So you know about that.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: A D.A.'s man took me down to Lido. Turned out he knew more about it than I did. He knew Owen Taylor wanted to marry your sister -- once.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (quietly) Perhaps it wouldn't have been a bad idea. He was in love with her. We don't find much of that in our circle... (changing her tone) But I didn't come to see you about Owen. Do you feel yet that you can tell me what my father wants you to do?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not without his permission.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Was it about Carmen?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I can't even say that. Vivian watches him for a moment, then gives in. She takes a thick white envelope from her bag and tosses it on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You'd better look at this anyway. Marlowe examines the envelope.  45.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: A messenger brought it this morning.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Eight-thirty-five it says -- for you or your father. He opens the envelope, takes out a medium-sized photograp We do not see the subject of the picture, but Marlowe's reaction is significant. He whistles softly.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So that's what Carmen looks like! (to Vivian) How much do they want for this?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Five thousand -- for the negative and the rest of the prints. The deal has to be closed tonight, or they give the picture to some scandal sheet.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The demand came how?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: A woman telephoned me, shortly after this thing was delivered.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: There's nothing in the scandal sheet angle. Juries convict on that racket without leaving the box. what else is there?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Does there have to be something else? Marlowe nods -- his face is uncompromising.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (giving in again) The woman said there was a police jam connected with it, and I'd better lay it on the line fast or I'd be talking to my little sister through a wire screen.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (deadpan, nodding) What kind of a jam?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I don't know.  46.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Where's Carmen now?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: She's at home -- still in bed, I think. She was sick last night.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: She go out at all?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: The servants say she didn't. I was up at Las Olindas across the State line playing roulette at Eddie Mars' Cypress Club. I lost my shirt. (taking another cigarette -- laughing wryly)

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (getting up to hold the match for her) So you like roulette. You would.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Yes, the Sternwoods all like losing games. The Sternwoods can afford to. The Sternwoods have money. (bitterly) All it's bought them is a raincheck.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What was Owen doing with your car last night?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Nobody knows. He took it without permission. Do you think...?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He knew about this photo? (shrugging) I don't rule him out... Can you get five thousand in cash right away?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I can borrow it -- probably from Eddie Mars. (sardonically) There's a bond between us, you see. Shawn Regan ran away with Eddie's blonde wife.  47.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (turning away -- leaving a pause) You may need the money ina hurry.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: How about telling the police?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You know better than that. The police might turn up something they couldn't sit on -- and then where would the Sternwoods be? (after a pause) How was it left?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: The woman said she'd call me back with instructions at five.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Okay -- call me here as soon as you've heard from her.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Can you do anything?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I think so. But I can't tell you how -- or why.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I like you. You believe in miracles.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (laughing) I believe in people believing they're smarter than they are -- if that's a miracle. Have a drink? He reaches down into the desk drawer.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I'll have two drinks. Marlowe grins at her. He comes up with a bottle and two glasses, fills them, and takes one to her. They salute, start to drink and find that their eyes have met over the glass rims and refuse to come apart. Vivian breaks it, no because she is shy or coy, but because suddenly there is sadness in her face. Her gaze drops briefly, then returns to Marlowe, clear, steady, and sad.  48.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You're a lot like Shawn Regan. Marlowe looks at her, almost with tenderness and understanding.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You want to tell me now or later?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What you're so anxious to find out.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: It couldn't be -- you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Let's do one thing at a time.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (rising) I think we've done enough for one day...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (gently) Want that other drink?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (going toward door) No... Marlowe sets his glass down on the desk and picks up the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You forgot this. She turns by the door as he approaches, holding out her hand for the envelope. Marlowe gives it to her, but doesn't let go of it. They are not thinking about the envelope. Slowly he bends to her -- she leans back against the wall, her lips parte her eyes soft, misted with tears. Marlowe's mouth covers hers. Presently they break -- Vivian puts her hand on Marlowe's cheek.  68. 69. 49.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (softly) Your face is like Shawn's too -- clean and thin, with hard bones under it... She turns, neither slowly nor fast, away from him, opens the door, and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked unobtrusively under some trees a reasonable distan from Geiger's house. Marlowe sits patiently, waiting, his hat pushed to the back of his head, his collar loosened, smoking quietly. Presently, in b.g. in front of Geiger's house, Carmen Sternwood appears furtively around the far end of the hedge, and goes quickly in through the gap leading to the front door. Marlowe reacts, then gets out, to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: standing in an attitude of terror, her back pressed again the wall beside the front door to Geiger's house, staring at Marlowe as he enters. She raises one hand and clenches her teeth on her thumb, staring at him. The terror fades little as she recognizes him. She wears coat, hat, veil, etc.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Remember me now, don't you? Doghouse Reilly, the man that didn't grow very tall. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (making an effort to seem natural) Is this your doghouse?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure. Let's go inside, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (shrinking, cringing) Inside?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You wanted to get in, didn't you? He pushes her away, unlocks the door, pushes it inward.  70. 50.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: In with you. He shoves Carmen in ahead of him, follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carmen standing, looking about the room, as Marlowe shuts the door and stands looking at Carmen. She feels him watching her, smiles at him. He doesn't answer it. The smile fades. Marlowe takes out pack of cigarettes, offers it. She shakes her head dumbly, staring at him. He lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How much do you remember about last night?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Remember what? I was sick last night. I was home.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure you were. I mean, before you went hone. In that chair yonder -- on that orange shawl while they were taking pictures. Quit stalling. (staring at him, she starts to put her thumb in her mouth again) And stop biting your thumb too.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: You -- were the one?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Me. How much do you remember?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Are you the police?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. I'ma friend of your father's. (a moment ) Who killed him?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (faintly) Who else... knows?  51.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: About Geiger? Not the police, or they'd be camping here. (a moment ) Maybe Joe Brody.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Joe Brody? Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure. Not Steve Brody: Joe Brody. Did Joe kill him?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Kill who?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Look sister. I don't know how much trouble you are accustomed to, but I hope you've had plenty of practice dodging it.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (nods her head) Yes. Joe did it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why? (she watches him out of the corners of her eyes, biting her thumb; he draws on cigarette, expels) Seen much of him lately?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: No! TI hate him!

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So you're all ready to tell the cops he did it, huh? (quickly, as she stares at him) That is, if we can just get rid of that photograph Geiger made last night.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Photograph? What photograph?  She turns She gives 52.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (drags at cigarette, expels smoke) Just like last night. What a scream we are. Sternwood and Reilly, two stooges in search of a comedian.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Your name isn't Reilly. It's Marlowe. Vivian told me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So you are beginning to remember. And you came back to look for the photograph, but you couldn't get into the house. (she stares at him) The photo's gone. I looked for it last night. Brody took it with him.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: I've got to go home now.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure. But I wouldn't tell the police about Brody yet. Don't even tell a soul you were ever here -- either last night, or today. Net even Vivian. Leave it to Doghouse Reilly. Where's your car?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: On the back street, where nobody would see it. to go out as he turns to follow.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're not going to tell anybody we were here, are you?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (gives him a swooning look) It depends. I never tell on people who are nice to me. him a languishing, swooning, inviting look, so that her attitude is a caricature of what her more brilliant and vivid sister's might be. Marlowe grasps her arm almost savagely, turns her toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Come on. Get out of here --  53. He stops; they both react as FEET SOUND beyond the doer approaching, they pause dead as the BELL RINGS. While the stand staring at each other, Carmen drooling almost with terror, the BELL RINGS AGAIN, ceases, then SOUND of KEY a the lock and a moment later the door opens and EDDIE MARS enters quickly and then stops dead, staring at them. He i a handsome, hard, horsy-looking man in beautiful, restrained, expensive clothes, who stands staring at them with complete composure for a moment. Then he looks at Carmen, shuts the door, takes his hat off.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Excuse the casual entrance. The bell didn't answer. Is Mr. Geiger around?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. We don't knew just where he is. We found the doer open and stepped in.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: I see. Friends of his?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Just business. We dropped in for a book. Mars stares hard at Marlowe, who stares just as hard back.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: But we missed him. (takes Carmen's arm, pushes her toward door to pass Mars) So we'll trot along. As Marlowe is about to shoulder Mars aside to pass, Mars himself steps aside until Carmen has passed him, then he moves in between Marlowe and the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: The girl can go. But I'd like to talk to you a little. Marlowe stares at him, then makes a slight motion toward the gun inside his coat.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Don't try it. I've got two boys outside in the car. He turns, opens the door, Carmen scuttles through it. Mar shuts the door behind her, looks about the room.  54.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (puts hat back on) There's something wrong around here. I intend to find out what it is. If you want to pick lead out of yourself, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: A tough guy. Mars makes no answer. He walks on into the room, looking around. Marlowe watches him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I suppose it's all right if I smoke. Mars does not answer. He looks about, sees the totem pole is astonished, approaches it, stops suddenly as he moves the small rug over the bloodstain with his foot, then kneels swiftly out of sight for an instant beyond the des When he rises, he is facing Marlowe and his hand is just emerging from inside his coat, holding a Luger pistol.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Blood. On the floor there, under the rug. Quite a lot of blood.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (in interested tone) Is that so? Mars slides into the chair behind the desk, still watchin Marlowe, hooks the telephone toward him with the pistol- barrel, then shifts the pistol to his left hand and puts his right hand on the phone but without raising it.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: I think we'll have some law. Marlowe approaches while Mars watches him, and looks down at the stain, pretends to have seen it for the first time

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's old blood. Dried.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Just the same, we'll have some law.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Just who are you anyway?  55.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Marlowe's the name. I'ma private detective.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Who's the girl?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: A client. Geiger was trying to throw a loop on her. We came to talk it over. He wasn't here.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Convenient -- the door being open, when you didn't have a key.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Wasn't it? By the way, how'd you happen to have one?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Is that any of your business?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I could make it my business.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (smiles tightly) And I could make your business mine.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You wouldn't like it. The pay's too small.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: I own this house. Geiger is my tenant. Now what do you think of it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You know some nice people.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: I take them as they come. (he glances down at the pistol, shrugs, puts it back inside coat) Got any ideas, detective?  56.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: One or two. Somebody gunned Geiger. Somebody got gunned by Geiger, who ran away. Or Geiger was running a cult and made blood sacrifices in front of that barber pole there. Or he had meat for dinner and does his butchering in the front parlor. (Mars scowls at him) All right. I'll give up, then. Call your friends downtown.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: I don't get it. I still don't get your game here.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Don't you, Mr. Mars? Mars stares et Marlowe, who meets his stare steadily. Mars' face is now hard.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: You seem to be telling me Geiger was in a racket of some sort. What racket?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm not his landlord. And I'll tell you something else you missed. Somebody cleaned out whatever was in that back room in his bookshop today. Mars stares at Marlowe a long moment. Marlowe takes out a cigarette deliberately, is starting to light it.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: You talk too much. While Marlowe stands, the cigarette in his mouth, the matchbox resting in his hands, Mars suddenly whips out th pistol again, holds it on Marlowe, and whistles shrilly. SOUND of car door SLAMMING OFF, then RUNNING FEET.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Open the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Open it yourself. I've already got a client.  57.
