Mars rises, still holding the pistol on Marlowe, crosses toward the door as the SOUND OF FEET reaches the door and the knob is rattled from outside. Mars reaches the door opens it. Two men plunge into the room, already reaching inside their coats. One is a young hoodlum, good-looking, pale-faced boy, the other is older, slim, deadpan.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (jerks his head at Marlowe) Look him over... The slim man flicks out a short pistol, covers Marlowe. The boy approaches, searches Marlowe, who turns, helping the boy search him with the burlesqued air of a bored beauty modeling a gown in a shop.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Okay. No iron.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Find who he is. The boy draws Marlowe's wallet from his breast pocket, flips it open, studies the contents.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: A shamus. He strikes. Marlowe, moving faster, catches his wrist, wrenches it suddenly and sharply, so that in the next instant the wallet is in Marlowe's hand. The boy reacts angrily, but Mars stops it.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (sharply) That'll do. Beat it. The boy stops sullenly, glaring at Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (coldly vicious) I said, outside. The two guards withdraw, exit.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: All right. Talk. Marlowe deliberately finishes lighting the cigarette, inhales.  58.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not to you. I told you I've already got a client.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Who was it cleaned out the back of Geiger's store?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Quite a shower yesterday. Did it rain up there at Las Olindas?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (slaps the pistol angrily down on the desk) I might even make it worth your while to talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's the spirit. Leave the gun out of it. I can always hear money. How much of it are you clinking at me?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (slams the desk again with the flat pistol) I ask you a question, and you ask me another. My guess is, you need some help yourself. So cough up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not me. It's Geiger's kinfolk that need help -- provided a man like Geiger had anybody who loved him and will care who bumped him off. So I'd better give what I know to the Law. Which puts it in the public domain and don't leave me anything to sell. So I guess I'll drift. Marlowe makes a move to lift the gun, but does not.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (easily) By the way, how's Mrs. Mars these days? Mars' hand jerks at the gun, almost lifts it, pauses. He glares at Marlowe.  71. 72. 73. 59.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (almost whispers: raging inside) Beat it. Get out of here. Marlowe moves easily and unhurriedly toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe gets into his car. A short distance behind it Mars' car is parked, the two guards in it. Marlowe drives away. He expects a shot perhaps. As he drives away he burlesques it: holds his hand out the window as if he wer testing the air for rain. He drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sitting at his desk, the phone pulled up in front of him. He smokes nervously -- he seems to have been waiting some time -- and glances at his wristwatch. The PHONE RINGS. He grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah... What's the news?... Nothing -- you mean they haven't called you? (smiling sardonically) Mrs. Rutledge... You are not a very good liar. I thought you were going to trust me... (jerking the phone away from his ear with exaggerated haste) Why, Mrs. Rutledge! The PHONE CLICKS LOUDLY as the other end is slammed down the hook. Marlowe replaces his instrument slowly. He is not clowning now. He speaks softly to the telephone as though to Vivian herself, half in admiration, half in anger.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You crazy darn fool... He picks up his hat and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RANDALL PLACE
dialogues.text: on Marlowe, parked a few doors from the Randall Arms, obviously waiting for something.  74. 75. 76. 60.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RANDALL PLACE
dialogues.text: as Vivian drives up, parks, and enters the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RANDALL PLACE
dialogues.text: Marlowe gets out of his car and walks toward the Randall Arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe climbs the last steps. He walks down the hall to 405 and presses the bell. In one of the other apartments a radio plays softly. Presently the door of 40 opens noiselessly, just wide enough to show the man who stands behind it -- JOE BRODY, whom we have seen before, the back room of Geiger's store and later driving the pan truck. He looks steadily at Marlowe and does not speak. His right hand holds the door. A cigarette smolders in th corner of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Geiger?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (after a pause, deadpan) You said what?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Geiger. Arthur Gwynne Geiger. The guy with the blackmail racket. Brody's right hand drops slowly out of sight -- we get th impression he's reaching for a gun.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Don't know anybody by that name. Marlowe gives him a hard smile. Brody doesn't like the smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're Joe Brody?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So you're Joe Brody -- and you don't know anybody named Geiger. That's very funny.  77. 61.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Yeah? You got a funny sense of humor, maybe. Take it away and play it somewhere else. Marlowe leans against the door and gives him a dreamy smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You got Geiger's stuff, Joe. I got his sucker list. We ought to talk things over.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (glancing sideways into the room, then back to Marlowe) There's plenty of time to talk. Make it tomorrow, bud. He starts to close the door. Marlowe bares his teeth and shoves the door in against Brody, viciously.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) We'll make it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasant room, nicely furnished. French windows open onto a balcony; near the windows a closed door, and near the entrance another door with a heavy curtain drawn acro it. Marlowe closes the entrance door behind him, not taking his eyes from Brody. Brody stands still, his hand frozen underneath his coat, his eyes wolfish. Presently h breaks, letting his hand drop.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (shrugging -- turning away) Why not, if you think you got something. Marlowe smiles, glancing at the curtained doorway. A woman's shoes show below the edge.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You alone, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (meaningfully) Yeah. Marlowe lifts the curtain, high enough to show a very spiffy leg -- Vivian's, in fact. He admires it.  62.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I could be alone with that almost any time. He drops the curtain again, goes to the davenport, and si down, tossing his hat beside him. Brody picks up a box of cigars from a nearby table, walks to an easy chair opposi Marlowe, and sits.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm listening. He drops his cigarette stub into a tray and puts a cigar between his lips.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Cigar? He tosses one to Marlowe through the air. As Marlowe reaches out to catch it Brody takes a Police Special out the cigar box and covers Marlowe, who relaxes slowly, lik a steel spring.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Okay, stand up. Slow.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (not moving, smiling sardonically) My, my -- such a lot of guns around town, and so few brains. You're the second guy I've met today who seems to think a gat in the hand means the world by the tail. (derisively) Put it down, Joe. (as Joe doesn't move, only looks nastier) The other guy's name is Eddie Mars. Ever hear of him?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: If he ever gets wise to where you were last night in the rain -- you'll hear of him.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (deadpan, but lowering the gun) What would I be to Eddie Mars?  63.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not even a memory.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Don't get me wrong. I'm not a tough guy -- just careful.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're not careful enough. That play with Geiger's stuff was terrible. I saw it, you know. I don't think Geiger's boy friend liked it.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Carol Lundgren? That punk.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Punk burns, sometimes. (raises his voice to the curtain door) You might as well come out, Vivian. Brody decided not to shoot me just yet. (as the curtain parts slightly to show Vivian, undecided) Oh, yeah, and bring the blonde with you. Vivian comes out, followed by Agnes. Vivian looks strained, angry, indomitable. Agnes looks merely vicious.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (to Agnes) Hello, sugar.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (sourly) Hello -- trouble! Agnes flounces down on the arm of an overstuffed chair. Brody watches, his eyes hard and narrow, expressionless. Vivian stands looking down at Marlowe. She is definitely not glad to see him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So you don't really believe in miracles -- or me.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I've learned not to believe in anything. I don't need you, Marlowe. I don't know how you got here, but I don't want you. Will you get out?  64.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: But darling, the man with the gun won't let me. Look -- he's all bothered and curious, wondering about stuff.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (menacingly) Yeah -- you bet I'm wondering. (looking sharply from Vivian to Marlowe, then to Agnes) Agnes -- put some more light on so I can see to shoot if I have to. (to Vivian, as Agnes switches on a floor lamp) You -- sit down, and keep quiet.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Joe, I swear I didn't have anything to do...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (attempting to draw her down beside him) Don't argue with the man. Here... (taking Vivian's handbag, hefting it to assure himself the wad of bills is still inside, and grinning with satisfaction, placing bag on couch) Sit on this, baby... Go ahead. You won't need it.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Marlowe, you're ruining everything.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (finally losing patience, yanking her down bodily) Sit down! Vivian struggles with him angrily. Marlowe puts his arm around her and smiles mockingly at Brody, who raises his gun slightly, with unpleasant significance.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Okay, fella. Give out.  He rises, his sheer 65.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Uh-uh, Joe -- you're doing the giving.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (leaning forward, menacingly) Listen...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure, sure -- You're the hard boy with the gun. Okay -- go ahead, blow holes in me. That won't take the cops off your neck.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: What cops?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The cops that are going to find out where all that lead in Geiger came from. pacing with nervous catlike energy as he talks, ease and conviction holding Brody motionless.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You shot Geiger, last night in the rain. The trouble is he wasn't alone when you whiffed him. Either you didn't notice that -- and I think you did -- or you got scared and ran. But you had nerve enough to take the plate out of his camera, and you had nerve enough to come back later and hide his corpse, so you could clean out his store before the law knew it had a murder to investigate.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (dangerously quiet) It's kind of lucky for you I didn't kill Geiger.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You can hold your breath for it, just the same.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: You think you got me framed.  66.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Don't go simple on me, Joe. I told you there was a witness.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (suddenly seeing the light) Carmen! That little... She would -- just that! Vivian reacts to this -- Marlowe puts his hand strongly o her shoulder, holding her quiet!

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (laughing) I thought you had that picture of her. For a moment nobody moves. There is a feeling of predator animals; caged and waiting. Vivian looks slowly up into Marlowe's face. Then Brody puts his gun down on an end table by his chair.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Let's all calm down here. Let's all just sit quiet a minute and think. (to Marlowe) Who are you? And what do you get out of this?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm just a guy paid to do other people's laundry. And all I get out of it is those pictures of Carmen.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: What pictures?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (as to a child) Oh, Joe! He sits down beside Vivian again, talks to her as though Brody were not present.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How do you like that? He drops the whole thing in my lap, and then he says "What pictures"? (to Agnes) Poor Aggie. I hate to think of you standing outside the gas chamber watching him while he chokes.  67.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (to Brody) Joe...

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Shut up. (to Marlowe) How did you get to me?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I never saw so many streets leading to one place in my life. Everywhere I turn I fall over Joe Brody -- and I been doing a lot of turning.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: So Carmen says I gunned him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: With the photos in hand, I might be able to convince her she was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (after a pause, scowling) I'm not saying I have or haven't got the photos. I'm only saying I'm broke. Agnes and I are down to nickels, and we got to move on for a while till this Geiger thing cools off.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No dough from my client.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (to Vivian -- with cold fury) So you did go to somebody after all. (rising) All right! I don't need your five grand. I can take you off my back Marlowe, and I can get the cops taken off. I got a connection, see? I got a handle on something big enough to turn this town upside down --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why haven't you pulled it?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: I'm going to. And what I get out of it will make your five grand look like a roll of nickels.  68.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Joe -- you're not gonna do it. You can't go up against Eddie Mars, he'll --

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (furiously) Shut up! You have to let that big mouth run off in front of -- He is interrupted by the sudden RINGING of the DOORBELL. They hold it, all of them apprehensive of who may be on t other side of the door, while the RINGING STOPS and becom an insistent rapping. Brody jerks open a desk drawer and draws out a bone-handled automatic, which he hands out to Agnes. She takes it, shaking nervously. Brody indicates Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (to Agnes) If he gets funny, use your own judgment -- and the dame, too. Agnes sits on the arm of the davenport beside Marlowe, th gun out of sight against him. Marlowe, observing her shaking hand, is not happy. Brody puts his own gun in his pocket, leaving his hand on it, and opens the door. Carme Sternwood pushes him back in the room, using a tiny revolver which she pushes against his hips. Carmen kicks the door shut behind her; Agnes leaps up, standing out of Marlowe's reach, her gun wavering between him and Carmen. She remains oblivious of the other people in the room. Vivian reacts to her entrance, but says nothing. Marlowe sits still, automatically stroking the sleepy cat.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (to Brody, with quiet viciousness) I want my pictures, Joe. Brody is scared, playing it very easy, backing up as she follows him.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Carmen.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (sharply, eyeing Agnes) Carmen...

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (to Carmen) Get away from him, you.  69. Vivian rises sharply, also getting out of Marlowe's reach she whips a small automatic out of her coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (to Agnes, trying to watch her and Brody at the same time) Let her alone. (to Brody, moving toward him) Joe, if you dare to hurt her...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: This is cute. Hasn't anybody else got a gun? -- We can play ring around the roses.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (ignoring them all -- to Brody) You shot Arthur Geiger. I saw you. I want my pictures.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: For Pete's sake, all of you -- relax! No one hears him. The three women continue to behave like nervous cats -- the lead may start flying at anybody, any minute. Brody still has his hand in his pocket; he may blast Carmen -- and Marlowe, gunless, sits in the middle the possible crossfire. Vivian is closer to him than Agnes, having moved beyond the hampering arm of the couch Marlowe moves abruptly. Grabbing the couch cushion which Vivian has just vacated, he slings it at Agnes, knocking her off balance and down. Almost as a continuation of the same movement Marlowe mak a dive for Vivian's legs. She falls on top of him, they struggle for the gun, and Vivian bites Marlowe's wrist. H whacks her across the side of the head with his free hand wrenches the gun free and stands up. Carmen's attention has been distracted slightly by this dust-up, and Brody strikes at her gun hand. The gun goes off, making a small sharp crack, shattering a pane of glass in the French windows, then skitters out of Carmen's hand and across th floor. Agnes lets go a frightened bleat and collects herself, about to fire at Carmen. Marlowe makes a quick rush, kicks the gun out of her hand, and puts his foot on Carmen's gun just as Carmen gets there, her hands and knees, reaching. She puts her hand on Marlowe's foot, and then looks up at him, sidewise, and giggles. He bends ove and pats her on the back.  70.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Get up, angel. You look like a Pekinese. She draws back and rises as Marlowe scoops up her gun wit his left hand and drops it in his pocket. The gun he has taken from Vivian still dominates the room.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Everybody -- stand still. They do, and he walks over and picks up Agnes' gun, sticking that on in his hip pocket. Brody is wiping the nervous sweat off his face -- Agnes and Vivian still crou half stunned on the floor. Marlowe laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: My, don't we have fun! You can get up now, kiddies. (walking over to Brody) All right, Joe. Give. Brody goes sullenly to the desk, opens a secret compartme and pulls out a fat envelope, hands it to Marlowe. Marlow glances at the contents.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure this is all of it?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Now will you dust, so I can air out the room? Marlowe turns as the Sternwood girls approach him. Carmen gives him a languishing smile and holds out her hand for the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Can I have them now?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'll take care of them for you. He hands the envelope to Vivian, who thanks him with her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (to Carmen and Vivian) You'd better go on home now. Carmen continues to look at him, sidelong, biting her thu

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: You'll take care of Carmen, won't you?  71.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Check.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Could I have my gun back?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Later.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: You're awfully cute.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. (stopping Vivian as she passes him, heading toward the door) Countess -- you forgot something. He picks up her bag off the davenport and hands it to her -- the scene's almost a repetition of the one in Marlowe' office, with Marlowe still holding the handbag.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Did I hurt your head much?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (softly) You -- and every other man I ever met. She goes out. Carmen follows her, but at the door she turns impulsively, flings her arms around Marlowe's neck and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: I like you. She runs off down the hall. Marlowe looks at her, puzzled by her unusual attitude. He closes the door and turns again to Brody and Agnes. Agnes, considerably scratched up, gives him a snakely glare as she pats her wounds with handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: I got enough of you, chum.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but there's still some unfinished business. What's this handle you got on Eddie Mars that's big enough to turn the town upside down?  72.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Listen -- you got your pictures -- you got nothing more on me. Get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure, I can go. You can go, too. Up to Quentin, to the big chair in the little room with the window. They stand outside, Joe, with stopwatches. They clock you in seconds, but from where you sit the centuries stink of cyanide, and they wrap around your throat, and a lot of people say it's easier than hanging -- I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: What are you trying to do?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Keep your neck out of a noose -- in return for some information. Got an alibi for last night?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: I was right here with Agnes.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (picking up his hat) Okay, Joe. You can only die once, even for a couple of murders. Brody stares at him as he turns to leave. Agnes is scared -- she puts her hand on Brody's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. What do you mean -- a couple of murders?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: But then, you don't have to worry, do you? You got a connection.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (laughs, sits down on table edge) Where were you about seven-thirty last night?  73.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (sullenly) Watching Geiger's place, to see if he has any friends too big for me to kick out of the way when I take over his business. It's raining hard, I'm shut up in my car, and I don't see anything except another car parked in the alley below Geiger's. I look at it -- it's a Buick registered to Mrs. Rutledge. That's all. Nothing happened, and I got tired waiting and went home.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Know where that Buick is now?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: How would I?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: In the Sheriff's garage. It was fished out of twelve feet of water off Lido pier this morning. There was a dead man in it, Owen Taylor, the Sternwood's chauffeur -- the guy you got the pictures from. He'd been sapped and the car pointed out the pier and the hand throttle pulled down. Brody gives Marlowe a stricken look. Agnes tightens her grip on him.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Joe, you didn't...

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Shut up. (to Marlowe) You can't hang that one on me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I can make a good try -- unless you talk and talk straight.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: All right, all right! Yeah, I heard the shots. I see this guy come slamming down the back steps with something in his hand. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRODY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He shoots off in the Buick, and I follow him, and out of the highway he skids off the road and has to stop, so I stop too, and play cop. His nerve is bad, and I sap him down -- and I figure the film might be worth something, so I take it. That's the last I see of him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh -- so Taylor gave Geiger the works, and ail for the love of little Carmen. Agh! The sap!... How'd you know it was Geiger he shot?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Seemed like a good guess. When I saw what was on the film I was sure, and when Geiger didn't show at the store this morning, Agnes and I figured it was a good time to do ourselves some business.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you figured, all right. You businessed yourself right into a hot box.

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Yeah -- yeah, I guess I did.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I got connections too, you know, with the D.A.'s office. If I know about Eddie Mars I might be able to cool you down some.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: (as Brody hesitates) Go on, Joe -- tell him!

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: Okay. It's kind of a funny story. It ain't about Eddie Mars, really -- it's about his wife. I... The DOORBELL starts to RING. Brody stands up, with Agnes beside him. Marlowe stays put.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: If she is, she doesn't have her gun. Don't you have any other friends?

dialogues.speaker: BRODY
dialogues.text: (crossing to the table, picking up the Colt) Just about one. (going angrily to the door) I got enough of this. He opens the door about a foot, with his left hand, holdi the Colt ready by his thigh. It is impossible to see who stands in the hall. Almost instantly two shots sound, close together. Brody doubles up, falls forward against the door, slamming it shut. Agnes reacts, but does not scream. Marlowe leaps up, hauls Brody away from the door -- Brody is quite dead. Marlowe runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe runs toward the stairs. A frightened woman peers out of a doorway, pointing to the stairs. The SOUND of RUNNING FEET comes from the treads below. Marlowe race to the stairway and down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door is closing itself quietly as Marlowe races down the last flight of steps. He goes through the door catching it before it closes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RANDALL PLACE
dialogues.text: as Marlowe comes out, pauses to get his bearings.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RANDALL PLACE
dialogues.text: He runs between two parked cars diagonally across the street, whirls to fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as two shots sound -- we see the impact of the bullets on the wall beside Marlowe, too close for comfort.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RANDALL PLACE
dialogues.text: (MARLOWE'S ANGLE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Lundgren vanishes behind parked cars, in the dense tre shadows, running hard.  84. 85. 86. 87. 76.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RANDALL PLACE
dialogues.text: as Marlowe gets in his car and heads down the street, following Lundgren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a quiet residential street, with trees growing heavy alon the parkway. Marlowe's car pulls in to park. Marlowe gets out into the street, crouching low, and pulls Carmen's little gun from his pocket. He walks back the way he has come, crouching for shelter behind the line of parked car Aside from him the street is deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Carol Lundgren walks unconcernedly along, approaching Marlowe. He seems to feel that he's in the clear, even whistles softly as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lundgren draws abreast of him, Marlowe steps from between the parked cars, holding the gun at his side. An unlighted cigarette droops from his lips.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Got a match, bud? Lundgren stands still, taken by surprise, not sure what t do. His hand rises instinctively to his leather jacket, but not inside. A siren wails off, going toward the Randall Arms -- Lundgren turns his head instinctively toward the sound, and Marlowe steps in against him, the little gun jammed into Lundgren's midriff.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Me, or the cops?

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: Get away from me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: This is a small gun, kid. I can give it to you through the belly and in three months you'll be well enough to walk the last mile up at Quentin.  88. 89. 77. Lundgren holds it, glaring at Marlowe, then relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: LUNDGREN
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (turning -- indicating car) Get into my car, kid. (as Lundgren obeys -- slowly) Under the wheel. You drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lundgren slides under the wheel, from the curb side, and Marlowe gets in beside him, keeping him covered.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Let's go to Laverne Terrace -- Geiger's house. (pleasantly -- as Lundgren starts the car) And by the way, Carol -- if you shot Brody for friendship's sake, you shot the wrong guy. Lundgren gives him a hard, nasty look and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (softly) Not all friendship, was it? Yeah, money talks, all right. It talks, and it's breath smells of blood... (laughing to himself) I told Brody that sometimes punk burns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe and Lundgren stand on the footbridge. Marlowe still carries the toy gun. He pulls the keys out of his pocket with his left hand and gives them to Lundgren.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You open it. Lundgren starts to take the keys, then slams Marlowe a quick, hard punch on the jaw. Marlowe rocks back, but doesn't fall -- he smiles and throws the gun down at Lundgren's feet.  90. 91. 78.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Maybe you need this. Lundgren goes for the gun. As he bends down Marlowe steps in fast, bringing his knee up into Lundgren's face. The force of the blow straightens Lundgren up, and Marlowe uncorks a terrific left. Lundgren falls heavily. Marlowe, unperturbed, unlocks the door, puts the gun back in his pocket, and starts to drag Lundgren inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lundgren is stretched out on the couch, his hands bound behind him, under his back. A single lamp shines down int his face. He has bled somewhat from the nose. Marlowe sits on the couch, twisted sideways, so that Lundgren's head is strained back over his knee. Marlowe helps the straining by having his left hand wound in Lundgren's hai His manner is gentle, almost friendly.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (softly) You're going to cop a plea, brother -- don't ever think you're not. And when you talk, you're going to say just what I want you to say, and nothing else. You hear me, sweetheart? Lundgren makes no reply, staring stonily into the light.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (almost caressingly) It's your face, Carol. You can do what you want with it. He jerks Lundgren's head back harder and raises his free hand, bringing it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe stands at the telephone, speaking into the instrument. His face is beaded with sweat, his collar open. He smokes jerkily -- we get the impression he hasn' enjoyed slapping Lundgren around. In b.g. Lundgren lies on the couch, both hands over his face.  92. 93. 79.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, Bernie? -- Yeah, Marlowe. How you fixed for red points, Bernie...? Well, come on up to 7244 Laverne Terrace -- I got some cold meat set out... might interest you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand by the bed, looking down. Geiger is laid out on the bed. Two strips of Chinese embroidery cover the wounds on his breast, in the shape of a cross, his hands folded over them. The only light in the room comes from two black candles burning on either side of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Nice gesture of friendship. Lundgren?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Ohls bends over, lifts up the Chinese embroidery, studies Geiger's chest, then straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: So that's where the three slugs went out of Owen Taylor's gun. Well, I can understand that. (making a gesture of distaste) Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sprawled sideways on the couch, leaning his head against the wall, showing signs of his recent battle with Marlowe Marlowe sits in b.g., easily, smoking. Ohls stands over Carol. Ohls is annoyed with Marlowe, shows it in succeeding scenes.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (to Carol) Do you admit shooting Brody?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (not moving -- not opening his eyes) Take a jump, Jack.  94. 95. 80.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (through smoke) He doesn't have to admit it. I've got the gun.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (he rouses himself) I've called Wilde. Come on. We'll deliver this punk to him. He leans down, grasps Carol's arm.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Get up. (Carol flings his hand off -- rises sullenly -- Ohls moves in beside him) Come on, Marlowe. The D.A. will want to see the man that solves single-handed what we make busts on. And on the way to him, you and I will talk a little too. Marlowe rises, follows as Ohls takes Carol out, snapping off the lights as he passes them and all exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: indicating a city of some size, wealth, etc. The D.A. sit behind his desk. He wears a dinner jacket, has been calle hastily from a party obviously. At corner of the desk sit Captain Cronjager of the city police homicide detail, in plain clothes. He is a cold, hatchet-faced man obviously displeased with the way things have happened. Ohls enters followed by Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (to Wilde) Evening, Chief. Evening, Cronjager. (he pulls up a chair to sit down) Meet Sherlock Holmes, gentlemen. (to Marlowe) Grab yourself a chair -- unless you'd rather be on your feet while Cronjager gives you a going-over.  81.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: Sit down, Marlowe. We'll try to handle Captain Cronjager. But I think you'll admit you were going a little fast, won't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks. He sits down, takes out a cigarette, holds it unlighted i his hand. Ohls and Cronjager stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Fast is right. But just wait and watch him go when his foot finally does slip. (to Cronjager) Maybe you'd better tell Sherlock Holmes here what else you got on the Randall Place killing.

dialogues.speaker: CRONJAGER
dialogues.text: A blonde. Down on the street, trying to start a car that didn't belong to her. Hers was right next to it, the same model. She acted rattled, so the boys brought her in and she spilled. Claims she didn't see the killer.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (still riding Marlowe) He's in the back office now -- handcuffed. Here's the gun. He takes Carol's gun from his pocket, drops it on the des Cronjager looks at the gun, but without touching it. Afte a moment Wilde chuckles, enjoying Cronjager's discomfitur and Ohls' annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: But that's just one of them. (he stares at Marlowe while he addresses Cronjager ) You heard about a car being lifted out of the surf at Lido pier this morning with a dead guy in it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (mildly) Do you have to be coy about it?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (staring at Marlowe -- addressing Cronjager with malicious sarcasm) Sure. The guy they found drowned in the car shot another guy last night in your territory; a guy named Geiger who ran a racket in the back room of a bookstore on the boulevard. The punk I got in the back office worked for Geiger. (to Marlowe) You're on the air. Let's have it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's all. When I finally located the lad that moved the packing case out of Geiger's back room, Geiger's blonde secretary was with him. It was Brody. While I was trying to persuade Brody to tell what became of the packing case, the doorbell rang again and Brody opened the door and somebody shot him twice. You know the rest of it. (he lights his cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Except what was in the packing case -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (smoking) Brody didn't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (staring at Marlowe) You see, Cronjager? Even as smart as he is, he's got to guess sometimes, too.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: My guess is the same as yours. Black mailing stuff. Geiger's customers must have been wearing a path across that rug, coming in to knock on that locked door and pay their monthly installments.  83.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (staring at Marlowe) That's right, Cronjager. Maybe Sherlock's even going to show us his evidence for guessing that.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Do you folks still guess when you have evidence?

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: (sharply) That's enough of this. (to Marlowe) So Taylor killed Geiger because he was in love with the Sternwood girl. And Brody followed Taylor, sapped him and took the photograph and pushed Taylor into the ocean. And the punk killed Brody because the punk thought he should have inherited Geiger's business and Brody was throwing him out.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's how I figure it.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: (extends his hand) Let's see your evidence.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Give, pal. Hiding murders. Spending a whole day foxing around so that this punk of Geiger's can have plenty of time to commit another one. Marlowe takes from his coat and puts on the desk before Wilde the three notes and Geiger's card to General Stern wood, and the notebook with its code list of names. Wilde looks at them, lights a cigar. Ohls and Cronjager rise an look at the articles over Wilde's shoulders. Marlowe smokes quietly.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: (after a time) These notes. If General Sternwood paid them, it would be because he was afraid of something else. Do you know what he was afraid of?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No.  84. Wilde stares at Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Have you told your story complete?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I left out some personal matters. (they stare at each other) I intend to keep on leaving them out.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I've still got a client. You recommended me to him through Bernie. My first duty is to him. Wilde, Ohls and Cronjager all stare at Marlowe. He smokes quietly. Wilde, staring at Marlowe, makes a slight signal with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (to D.A.) Okay. But you're wasting time. If you'd let me handle Sherlock...

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: That'll do, Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (to Cronjager) I want to surrender a prisoner to you. Come on. (he goes toward door -- Cronjager following. As Ohls opens the door he pauses and looks back at Marlowe. To Marlowe: ) I like you. Better and better. Some day I'm going to like you so well I won't be able to bear having you out of my sight. He and Cronjager exit, close the door. Wilde puffs his cigar, staring at Marlowe. Marlowe smokes quietly.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: (after a time) Do you know why I'm not tearing your ear off?  85.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I expected to lose both of them.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: (smoking -- watching him steadily -- after a time) What are you getting for all this?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Twenty-five a day and expenses.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: And for that money you're willing to get yourself in Dutch with the law enforcement of this county, maybe lose your license?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (quietly) I've still got a client.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: Is he still just a client? (Marlowe doesn't answer -- smoking) Listen to me, son. My father was a close friend of old General Sternwood. I like him as well as you do. I've done all my office permits -- maybe a good deal more -- to save him from grief. But in the long run, nothing can save him except dying.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- the big sleep. That'll cure his grief.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: It cures all the grief... You really don't know yet what General Sternwood wants with you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes. To settle this business with Geiger.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: He's afraid that ex-bootlegger Regan, that he took up about a year ago, is mixed up in this somewhere. What he really wants is for you to find out that Regan isn't.  96. 97. 86.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Regan's no blackmailer. I knew him. Wilde shrugs slightly.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: Maybe you'd better find him and prove it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Maybe I had. Marlowe rises. He indicates the objects on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Can I have these? Wilde looks again at the objects, then he takes up the notebook containing the code names and addresses, opens t desk drawer, drops the book in and shuts it, pushes the other things across the desk toward Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: WILDE
dialogues.text: Take them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he unlocks the entrance, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he enters, is shutting the door when a man, the only occupant, sitting with a newspaper in a lobby chair, lowe the paper. It is the young hoodlum who was with Mars at Geiger's house this morning. He rises, flicks his cigarette stub into a potted palm and thrusts the tip of his right hand into the V of his coat-opening.

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: (jovially) Well, well, if it ain't Hawkshaw himself. The boss wants to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: What do you care, Hawkshaw? Just keep your nose clean. Let the boss do all the thinking and ask the questions.  98. 87.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (drops hand into side pocket) I'm too tired to talk. Too tired to think too. But if you think I'm too tired to refuse to take orders from Eddie Mars -- try getting your gat out before I shoot that good ear off. (bodyguard stares at him -- undecided)

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: A comedian, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm going to die laughing in just about a minute.

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: (baffled) You ain't got no gun. Have you forgot about this morning?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That was this morning. I'm not always barefooted. The bodyguard stares at Marlowe a while longer. Then he waves his left hand airily.

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: Okay, hot shot! You win. But don't let it go to your head, see? (moves toward the door) You'll hear from us.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Too late will be too soon. The bodyguard crosses to the street door, exits. Then Marlowe follows to the door, sees it is locked, turns, hi lip twisted in contempt, and crosses toward elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he enters, snaps on light, tosses his hat onto the bed takes Carmen Sternwood's little pistol from his pocket, tosses it onto table beneath the lamp, crosses to bookcas on which a bottle of whiskey sits, takes up the bottle an goes on to the kitchen, exits. OVER SOUND OF REFRIGERATOR DOOR, CLINK OF GLASS, ETC.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: at table beneath the lamp, half-emptied highball beside him, as he finishes cleaning Carmen's pistol. He closes the pistol, and holding it in his left hand, he gathers u the remaining tiny shells he had removed from it, examine them, shrugs sardonically, tosses them into desk drawer closes drawer and is folding a greased rag about the pist when the telephone rings. He puts the pistol on the desk and turns.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE AT TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: He holds the receiver lowered somewhat, so that Mars' harsh voice comes clearly from it.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: So you're tough tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sleepy, too. What can I do for you, Mister Mars?

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Cops over there -- you know where. Did you keep me out of it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Listen, soldier. I'm nice to be nice to.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You listen. Maybe you'll hear my teeth chattering.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: (laughs shortly) Did you -- or did you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I did. I don't know why, but I did.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Thanks, soldier. Who gunned him?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Somebody you never heard of. Let it go at that.  101. 89.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: If that's on the level, someday I may be able to do you a favor.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You can now. Hang up and let me go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: (laughs again) You're looking for Shawn Regan, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Everybody I meet seems to think I am. But I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: If you were, I could give you an idea. Drive up to the club and see me. Any time.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Be seeing you then. The other receiver clicks. Marlowe puts his receiver down slowly, sits a moment, thoughtful. He seems to be waiting for something. He takes out a cigarette, has just struck the match when the phone rings. Without moving he blows out the match and wedges the paper stem into the telephon bell, muffling it, so that it now merely buzzes, steadily as whoever it is continues to ring. Then he strikes another match, lights the cigarette, rises and begins to unknot his tie as he walks out of SHOT. The muffled telephone buzzes, the light snaps off, leaving the room i darkness. The muffled phone continues to buzz as whoever it is keeps on ringing. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: lettered: Bureau of Missing Persons

dialogues.speaker: INT. OFFICE DAY
dialogues.text: Marlowe seated, facing across the desk Captain Gregory, a slow, burly man who looks dull and stupid but is not. Gregory in plain clothes looks at Marlowe's credentials, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Private, eh? What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm working for General Guy Sternwood. The D.A. knows him.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: I know who he is too. Did the D.A. send you here?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Isn't your information available to anybody, unless it' a homicide matter?

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Did the D.A. send you here?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Did he know you were coming?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (after a moment -- takes out cigarettes) Mind if I smoke?

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (lights up) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I want to know what became of a man named Shawn Regan, who used to work for General Sternwood.  g1.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: I don't know where he is. He scrammed -- pulled down the curtain, and that's that.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Will you give me what you have got on him? Gregory rings a bell on desk-edge. The door opens, a middle-aged woman secretary enters.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Get me the file on Shawn Regan, Abba. The woman exits. Marlowe smokes. Gregory takes up a charred pipe, digs tobacco dottle deliberately from it, i about to fill it when the woman enters, lays an official file on the desk, exits. Gregory puts down the pipe, puts on glasses, opens the file.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: He blew on the sixteenth of September. No one reported it. We got into it by finding the car. It was the chauffeur's day off, so nobody at Sternwood's saw Regan take his car out of the garage. We found the car four days later in a garage belonging to a ritzy bungalow court on Sunset. The garage man reported it to the stolen car detail; said it didn't belong there. We couldn't find who it belonged to.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And of course Eddie Mars' wife couldn't tell you, because she had disappeared too.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: (stares at Marlowe a moment ) If you knew so much already, why did you come to me?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: So you have been talking to some Sternwood about Regan.  92.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why not? You just said nobody has accused anybody of any crime yet.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Mars was gone too, disappeared within two days of the day Regan's car was left in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What are the angles?

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mars lived in the apartment the garage belonged to. Regan was known to carry a roll, fifteen grand, in his clothes all the time --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes. I had heard that.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: It don't seem to have been any secret to anybody that Regan was sweet on Mars' wife.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So it looks like they went off together.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Regan had fifteen grand in cash with him. Mrs. Mars had some rocks, and a car of her own -- making two cars available. Everything disappeared but one of the cars.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What did she look like? Have you got a photograph?

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: No... A blonde. She won't be now though.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What was she before she married Mars?

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: A torcher.  103. 104. 93.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Maybe she isn't anything now. Maybe neither of them are.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: You're thinking of Eddie Mars. You're wrong. Mars is a business man, and a good one. Jealousy's a luxury -- murdering for it, at least -- that a man like Eddie Mars knows he can't afford.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So, as far as you're concerned, Mars is out.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: Mars is out. And, until something more turns up, we are too.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (rising) And so am I, it looks like. There's no law on my book either against a man with fifteen grand going away with the woman he loves. (turning) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GREGORY
dialogues.text: (closing the file) Not at all. (Marlowe moving toward the door) Give my best to the D.A.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (half halts -- being slyly kidded) I will. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gets into his car, drives away. As he does so, a coupe starts up behind him, following him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: is aware that the other car is following him, is sardonic is careful to let the other car keep in sight of him.  105. 106. 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: entering, finds Norris waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (closing door) Good morning, Norris.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (rises) Good morning, Mr. Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How's the General this morning?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Not so well, sir. I -- ah --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah? What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (in sort of a rush) I read the papers to him this morning. From -- ah -- certain items we assume that your investigation is now complete.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes, as regards Geiger. I didn't shoot him, though.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Quite so, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I guess you've called for the debris.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: The debris, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (crossing to other door) This way. Norris follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at desk takes out papers, evens them, puts them into envelope.  95.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: There you are. Three notes, and the card.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (steadily) Thank you, sir. Mrs. Rutledge tried several times to telephone you last night --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I know. I was busy getting tight.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (puts hand inside coat) Quite so, sir. (he draws out check hands it to Marlowe) The General instructed me to hand you this. Will it be satisfactory?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (takes check, glances at it, folds it) Five hundred. Quite.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (curiously insistent) And we may now consider the entire incident closed?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (gets the overtone but covers completely, easily) Sure. Tight as a vault with a busted time lock.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. We all appreciate it. When the General is feeling better, he will thank you himself.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll come out and drink some more of your brandy. Maybe with champagne.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (departing) I'll see that some is properly iced, sir.  107. 108. 96. He exits, closes the door. Marlowe's air changes now. He opens the check slowly, looks at it, speculatively.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (musing: aloud) Completely closed... completely closed. He rouses, puts the check into his wallet, goes to phone, dials, speaks into phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hello... Let me speak to Eddie... Sure, Eddie... Phil Marlowe. (holding phone between head and shoulder, he takes out cigarette, is about to light it, speaks into phone, still holding cigarette and burning match in both hands) Hello, Eddie. I want to see you. I'll drive up tonight... Check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: checking his hat and coat at counter. The slim, pasty- faced bodyguard who had been with Mars and the other guar at Geiger's house enters, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hello. How's the pistol-packing business up here?

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: (blandly) Better. We don't have so many amateurs around.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not amateurs -- just suckers, huh?

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: (turning) This way.  109. 97. Marlowe follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is suave, restrained, well-furnished, shows money. A wall safe in one wall, radio, liquor cabinet, comfortable chairs, etc. Mars wears a well-cut, expensive dinner suit. He shakes hands with Marlowe as the bodyguar withdraws, shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Took you a long time to get here, didn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be here now if you hadn't hinted you had something for me.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (turns to liquor cabinet, opens it, starts to fix drinks) What did you change your mind about? About what you are after, or just about admitting it? Marlowe, lighting a cigarette, doesn't answer. Mars prepares the highballs, approaches, hands one to Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (taking drink) Thanks. Mars leans against the desk, elegant, holding his drink.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: A friend of yours is outside playing the wheels. I hear she's doing well. Mrs. Rutledge -- (Marlowe says nothing, drinks) I liked the way you handled that yesterday. You made me sore at first. But I see now you knew what you were doing. You and I ought to get along. (Marlowe says nothing, drinks, smokes. Mars watches him) But I like to pay my checks as I go along. How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: For what?  98.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Still cagey, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: All right. How much have you got that I can use?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (waves hand, easy) Oh, that. I heard you had all the information already.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I don't know. You didn't bump Regan off, did you?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: No. So you think I did?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I came up here to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (stares at Marlowe) You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm kidding. I used to know Regan. You haven't got the men for that work. And while I think of it, don't send me any more gun punks. I might get nervous and shoot one of them. Mars stares at Marlowe, lifts glass and drinks, staring a Marlowe across the glass, lowers the glass.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: You talk a good game, but I still think we can get along. Are you looking for Regan, or not?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Geiger was trying to blackmail General Sternwood. I finally figured out that at least half the General's trouble was being afraid Regan might be behind it.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: I see. Well, Sternwood can turn over now and go back to sleep. It was Geiger's own racket. I like to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: know who rents anything from me, so I did some inquiring today myself. So if it was just Geiger you were after, whoever gunned him washed you and Sternwood both up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (sets glass down, rises) I guess that's what the General thinks too since he paid me off today. (Mars takes up Marlowe's empty glass) No thanks. No more.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Another won't hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (sets glass down) I'm sorry about that. I wish Sternwood would hire you ona straight salary to keep these girls of his home at least a few nights a week. (he drains his glass, sets it down, wipes his mouth) They're plain trouble. The older one's a pain in the neck around here. If she loses, she plunges, and I end up with a fist full of paper not even worth the ink on it. If she wins, she takes my money home with her.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Don't you get it back the next night? you g g

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: She's spent it by then.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And is back on the cuff, huh? Mind if I look the joint over?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Go ahead. (indicates small door) That comes out behind the tables.  100.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll go in with the other suckers.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: As you please. We're friends, aren't we? They shake hands. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Maybe I can do you a real favor some day.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Maybe! There's just one thing puzzling me, Eddie. You don't seem in much of a rush to find your wife. From what I hear she's not the kind of a wife a guy wants to lose. Could it be you know where she is -- with Regan?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (deadly quiet) Look, soldier... What's between me and my wife is between us.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Okay. Sorry. (he goes to door, turns) You don't have anybody watching me, tailing me around in a gray Plymouth coupe, do you?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (sharply, surprised, actually innocent of it) No. A gray Plymouth? When?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Then it don't matter. If it's not you, it's just an enemy. I can take care of him. Mars stares after him.  110. 141. 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: leans against small, swank bar, looking into the gambling room, which is big, spacious, various small lay-outs alon the wall. At the end of the big room are three roulette wheels. The two outside ones are deserted; even the croupiers have been drawn into the crowd which is packed densely about the middle one. In the center of the crowd VIVIAN'S HEAD can be seen as she plays her winning streak Marlowe is watching her. On the fringe of the crowd the waiters stand also, watching. All this is a build-up to show a phenomenal run which Vivian is making. The barman leans on the bar behind Marlowe

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: She's sure picking them tonight. She comes here a lot, and from the way it's been running for her, she's due to pick them. Put it's been a long time since this place seen anything like that. Two men emerge from the crowd about the wheel and approac the bar, excitedly. The barman moves to them, waits.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MAN
dialogues.text: (to Barman) Scotch and soda. (the barman starts the drinks. The speaker mops his face) Boy, I never saw such a run. Eight wins and two stand-offs in a row on that red. Betting a grand at a crack too.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: (serves the two drinks) A grand at a crack, huh? I saw an old horse-face in Havana once -- Marlowe moves away as the two men take up their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP AT WHEEL
dialogues.text: as he reaches the crowd. The play has stopped. The croupiers of all three wheels are now facing Vivian acros the table. A mass of bills, chips, etc., before Vivian.  102.

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: If you will just be patient a moment, Madame. The table cannot cover your bet. Mr. Mars will be here in a moment.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (looks about, cool, insolent, though her face shows excitement ) What kind of a cheap outfit is this? Get busy and spin the wheel. I want one more play and I'm playing table stakes. You take it away fast enough, I notice. But when it comes to dishing it out, you begin to whine.

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: The table cannot cover your bet, Madame. (indicates her pile) You have over sixteen thousand dollars there.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: It's your money. Don't you want it back?

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: (beside her, much more excited than she is) Look, lady --

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (turns on him, vicious, cutting) Do you want another sixteen thousand of it? The man falls back, discomfited. A door opens in the wall behind the table. The crowd falls silent, turns, as Mars comes out the door, smiling, indifferent, immaculate, han in his jacket pockets as he strolls to the table.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Something the matter, Mrs. Rutledge? (she is about to speak when he continues, easily, courteous) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you're not playing any more, you must let me send someone home with you.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: One more play, Eddie. All of it on the red. I like red. It's the color of blood. Mars stares at her a second, smiles faintly, takes from h inner breast pocket a large pinseal wallet with gold corners, very elegant, and tosses it carelessly to the croupier without opening it.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Cover her bet in even thousands. (to the gaping crowd) If no one objects to this turn of he wheel being for the lady alone. ct The crowd remains breathless. Vivian leans down and shove the whole mass of her winnings savagely onto the RED diamond of the layout, stands back. The croupier leans without haste and rapidly and skillfully counts the money stacks it, places all but a few scattered chips and bills rakes these into a neat pile and pushes it off the layout with his rake, leaving the bet on the RED. Then he opens Mars' wallet with the same detached deliber swiftness, draws out two flat packets of thousand-dollar bills. He breaks the tape around one, counts off six bills, adds them to the unbroken packet, puts the four other bills back into Mars' wallet and lays the wallet aside as carelessly as if it were a packet of paper matches. Mars does not touch the wallet. He stands as before, elegant, detached, courteous. The croupier spins the wheel with one hand, snaps the ball into it with the other, draws back and folds his arms.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN'S FACE
dialogues.text: as she watches the spinning wheel.

dialogues.speaker: WHEEL
dialogues.text: as it spins, slows, stops.

dialogues.speaker: CROUPIER
dialogues.text: Red. Odd. Second dozen.  115. 116. 117. 118. 104. Vivian laughs, triumphant, for the first time her excitem seems to come through as she lets go for the moment. Then she stops, watches the croupier add the bills to her bet, then with the rake shove the whole thing across to her. Mars smiles faintly, expressionless still, takes up the wallet, puts it back into his pocket, goes back to the do and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at the checkroom, gets his hat and coat, drops a coin int plate, goes toward the door, putting on coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: buttoning his coat, comes out, walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he enters, stops, looks about. His face is intent, watchful. He listens, puts his hand into his pocket, draw out a pipe, looks at it, tosses it slightly, contemptuous regretful, shrugs, thrusts pipe into his side-pocket, his hand still clutching it, goes on moving quietly and stealthily now, pauses, listens again, is about to go on when SOUND OF A SLIGHT COUGH comes from ahead. Marlowe steps quickly and soundlessly into the shrubbery.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: hidden behind a shrub, peering out. Ten feet away another man crouches behind a shrub beside the path, watching the path. He turns his head; we see that he wears a mask. He watches the path again, reacts as FAINT SOUND OF FEET begins. Vivian enters, walking rapidly along the path, clutching her handbag to her. As she passes the shrub, th man steps quickly out. Vivian stops but makes no sound.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: (quickly; low-tone) This is a gun, lady. Gentle now. Just hand me the bag. For a moment Vivian does not move. Then she draws a deep breath as if to scream, still clutching the handbag.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: Yell, and I'll cut you in half. (he opens the bag, thrusts his hand inside) It better be here --  105.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (quietly, from behind him) Hi, pal. (the thug stops dead. After a second his empty hand starts to steal upward) Easy now. As Marlowe and the thug stare it out tensely, two shadowy figures emerge from the shrubbery. One of them slugs Marlowe from behind. As he falls, the other grabs for Vivian, apparently about to do the same for her. She lets out a wild scream and starts shooting from the pocket. On of the thugs cries out in mingled pain and anger -- in th distance people begin to shout -- the noise has attracted attention.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: You clumsy yap...

dialogues.speaker: SECOND THUG
dialogues.text: Let's get outta here. They run, vanishing into the dark shrubbery. Vivian crouches beside Marlowe, helping as he tries to sit up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (in pain, holding his head) Agh -- good thing I got a thick skull -- People from the club, parking attendants, etc., run up. Flashlights play on them.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: (ad lib) What's the matter?... What happened? . The guy's hurt...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (rising groggily) It's okay. Just a slight holdup -- the lady flashes too much dough around. (to Vivian) You all right?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Yes -- are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Let's go. I don't like crowds.  106. They get away from the curious onlookers, walking down a dark path toward the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You got a car with you?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I came with a man. He's dead drunk. Forget him. What are you doing here, besides playing bodyguard?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: We both seem to have been doing a bit of that -- Eddie Mars wanted to see me.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He changed his mind. He never did tell me.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You lie.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: All right. I'm lying. They walk on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: enter, cross to Marlowe's coupe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (pauses) What are you trembling for? Don't tell me you're scared, because I won't believe that.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (draws him on) I wasn't used to being high-jacked. Give me a little time.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: High-jacked. That's -- all it was?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: What else?  107.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (studying the holes in her coat) You always go heeled?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I feel safer, around the heels I go with.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (laughing) You're terrific.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE'S COUPE
dialogues.text: He helps her in, gets in, shuts door, starts engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is going pretty fast, Marlowe intent on the road. Vivian seems nervous, is looking about, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (smoking nervously) So Eddie had you come all the way up here and then wouldn't tell you what he wanted? (dryly) . . That's right. I'm still lying. Suddenly she flings the cigarette out the window.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Have you got a drink?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure. (still driving, watching the road, he leans, takes a flask from dashboard compartment, hands it to her)

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (takes flask) I can't drink like this. Stop the car. Marlowe stops the car.  108.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (puts flask unopened back into compartment, slams it shut) I don't want a drink. Let's talk.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Do we need to? The General paid me off today -- I'm all washed up.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: All right. What's Eddie Mars got on you?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (easily; lifts the handbag, slaps it) This, for instance. And tonight's not the first time.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Which would make Eddie Mars sore. So we'll pass that and start over. What's he got on you?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Wittier, please, Marlowe. Wittier.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I can't. I'm too old to learn now.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: But not old enough to outgrow some of your other habits.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: For instance?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Killing people. (she stares at him, secretive, while he tries to follow her, catch up with what's going on) So you're a killer.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Does that mean Geiger, or Brody -- or maybe both of them?  109.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Why not? (she looks at him. Suddenly her manner changes; she speaks with a quiet and complete sincerity) I wish I was sure you had done it. Then I could thank you -- in my father's name. He still has pride, at least.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And you and your sister haven't.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (with bitter contempt) Carmen and me... (rapidly) We're his blood. That's where the hurt is. That Father might die despising his own blood. It was always wild, but it wasn't always rotten. (she pulls herself together, takes out a cigarette, slumps back in the seat as Marlowe strikes a match. But when he holds the match to her, he sees her lying back in the seat, the cigarette in her mouth, looking at him with lazy and inviting challenge. When he brings the match near, without moving she blows it out. When she speaks it is almost a whisper) Move closer. Marlowe stares at her. After a moment he flings the dead match deliberately away, puts his arm around her approaches his face to hers. Suddenly Vivian flings the unlighted cigarette over her shoulder toward the window, clasps him in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Hold me close!  110. They kiss, a long kiss. Marlowe raises his head at last.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hobart Arms.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I've never seen it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Would you like to?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What's Eddie Mars got on you? She is motionless in his arms for a second. Then she flings him back with one arm, sits violently up.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: So that's the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (controls herself; takes out a wisp of handkerchief and scrubs her lips savagely with it) Men have been shot for less than this, Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Men have been shot for less than nothing. The first time we met I told you I was a detective. Get it through your lovely head. I work at it, lady. I don't play at it.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: What makes you think Eddie Mars has anything on me?  122. 123. 111.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: He lets you win a lot of money, then he has a gunpoke meet you in the back yard and take it all away from you. And you're not even surprised. You don't even thank me for saving it for you.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Do I need to tell you what I think of you, Mister Detective?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You don't owe me anything. Your father paid me. I owe you something for the kiss.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Let me congratulate you on keeping your head.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Maybe I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Take me home. Marlowe starts the oar again, drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Marlowe enters, closing the door behind him. The only light in the room filters in from a street lamp outside. Marlowe flings his hat carelessly toward a chair, evident out of long habit, and starts across the room toward the kitchen, in search of a drink and in too much of a hurry bother turning on lights.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: As Marlowe approaches, his body filling the f.g. As he reaches the kitchen door a lamp goes on suddenly behind him. He freezes, his body blocking the view of what is behind him. Then, as he turns slowly, we see past him -- Carmen Sternwood sits in an armchair, the one, in fact, into which Marlowe has pitched his hat. Carmen holds it up, smiling. She wears an evening gown, more or less covered by a light wrap.  112.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (coyly) . What does the hatcheck girl get for a tip?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (grimly ) I'm trying to think of something appropriate -- How did you get in here?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Bet you can't guess.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (bleakly, lighting a cigarette) Bet I can. You came in through the keyhole, like Peter Pan.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Guy I used to know around the poolroom.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: You're cute.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And getting cuter every minute. How did you get in?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: I showed your manager your card. I stole it from Vivian. I told him you told me to come here and wait for you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Fine. Now tell me how you're going to get out.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (slipping off her wrap) I'm not going. She looks at him -- a surprisingly honest, steady look. This is a different Carmen -- a puzzled, half-frightened girl who seems to be waking from a dream -- not sure she wants to, but unable to help herself. Marlowe looks back at her, nastily. But he senses a difference, and his voic is surprisingly gentle when he speaks.  113.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Listen, Carmen. I'm tired. I've had a hard day's work. I like you, I'm your friend, and any other time I'd be tickled to death to see you. But not now. Will you please go home?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (quietly, hungrily) Are you really my friend, Phil?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sure...

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: I need a friend, Phil... someone to -- She stops, apparently confused, groping for words.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Someone to what, Carmen?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: I don't know. She looks up at him again, searching his face. As though Marlowe is a magnet, she is drawn to her feet, still looking at him. She comes close, but does not touch him.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
