dialogues.text: (almost to herself) What is it in you?... I'm afraid of you, and yet... there's something straight and hard... Phil, I wish I'd met you before -- a long time ago...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (trying to Josh her out of it) Hey, hey... What's all this?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: I don't know. (angrily) Why did you have to come? I was all right. I was fine.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And now?  114.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (almost weeping) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Look -- you and I want to go on being friends -- and you shouldn't be here. (holding her wrap for her) Be a good girl. During this speech, Carmen seems to take the wrap. But th wrap falls on to the floor, revealing the fact that Carme is holding Marlowe's hand.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Do you think I can be a good girl?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I think. Carmen kisses his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: But don't you want me to try?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (trying to free his hand now) I just want you to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (clinging to his hand) You've got funny thumbs. Can I bite it? Before he can answer, she raises his hand, starts to put his thumb into her mouth. With a sharp violent motion he flings her hand away.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Stick to your own thumb. Hasn't it carried you all right all your life?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (obediently) All right. She puts her thumb in her mouth, or her hand to her face such a way as to appear to be sucking her thumb as usual. Marlowe takes up the fallen wrap and approaches with it.  115.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Okay. Take your thumb now and get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: __ CARMEN
dialogues.text: (giggling) It's not my thumb. See? She removes the object from her mouth and holds it up for him to see. It is the white queen from his set of chessmen. Marlowe stares at her for a moment, then he slaps her terrifically across the face, rocking her back. The chessman falls from her hand and she stares at Marlow frightened now, as he walks toward her.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Do that again.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (seething with repressed rage; almost whispering) Get out.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Maybe if people had done that to me more often, I would have been good now. Marlowe reaches her, grasps he arm, hurries her across to the door, jerks the door open, almost hurls her through i flings the wrap after her, slams the door, turns the bolt as she rattles the knob, then begins to hammer on the doo He turns and crosses the room rapidly to the bath while s still beats on the door, and washes his hand savagely wit soap and water, his face now actually beaded with sweat. The KNOCKING CONTINUES. He examines his hand, is still no satisfied, jerks open shaving cabinet, looks at the innocuous bottles of mouthwash, etc., when what he needs carbolic acid, goes to the kitchen while the knocking sti continues, jerks savagely from the shelf his last bottle whiskey. It is about half full. He jerks the stopper out, flings i away and pours about a dollar's worth of expensive Scotch over his hand, flings the bottle away, returns to the living room, and while the KNOCKING STILL CONTINUES, he kneels at the hearth, lays the delicate chess piece on it and with a heavy fire-dog hammers the chess-piece into dust, still beating even after the piece has vanished, hi blows at last drowning out the SOUND of the knocking on t door.  124. 125. 116. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ringing. Marlowe wakes, rises onto elbow and takes the phone. He holds it loosely, so that we can HEAR OHLS' rasping VOICE from the other end.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Marlowe? Come down here. I want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I'm not up yet. I haven't had breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Never mind the breakfast. If you're not in my office in thirty minutes, you'll be eating it on the county. Ohls' telephone clicks shut. Marlowe puts his down, throws covers back to get up.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Lay off.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Lay off what?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: If you don't know what, it ought to be easy not to do it. They stare at each other. Ohls takes up a box of cigarett from the desk, offers it.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Smoke?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (not moving) I haven't had breakfast yet. Who says for me to lay off?  117.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: The D.A. does.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And beyond him?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: So you want to know. Okay it came from your client. That satisfy you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I haven't got a client. General Sternwood paid me off yesterday. I'm through.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Well, apparently he don't think so. And he's a friend of the D.A. and the D.A. is the chief crime prosecutor of this county, and I'm the D.A.'s head man Friday, and all three of us tell you to lay off.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Will you tell me one more thing: Why General Sternwood thinks I haven't laid off?

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: No. But I'll tell you what he might be thinking. That you are trying to uncover enough stuff about his family affairs to put the squeeze on him yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's a lie. General Sternwood never told the D.A. nor you nor anybody else that. I don't think the message even came from General Sternwood. It was -- (he stops, but Ohls has already broken in)

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: Never you mind what you think. You just lay off. You get it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (quietly) I get it. Or else I lose my license and take my pick and shovel out of the mothballs.  118. Thoughtful, he reaches out and takes a cigarette from the box.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: (watching him) Changed your mind, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (recovers, sees the cigarette in his hand, drops it back into the box) No. I haven't changed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TELEPHONE IS RINGING. Marlowe takes it up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes, speaking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wears hat and coat as if about to depart.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (rapidly) I've found Shawn. I'm leaving at once to meet him. We'll send you a picture postal from Mexico perhaps. So you can call off the bloodhounds, and many thanks. (she hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE AT PHONE
dialogues.text: as the click of Vivian's phone comes through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: facing Norris, who has answered the bell. Norris stands holding the door half open, as if barring Marlowe from entering.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (courteous, inscrutable) No, sir. She left no address. We don't expect to hear until she and Mr. Regan reach Mexico City perhaps.  130. 131. 132. 119.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So she found him.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (inscrutable) Yes, Sir. We are all most happy. -- Was there anything else?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The General...

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Is resting. I won't disturb him now.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Norris watches him, still barring him from entering. He turns. Norris closes the door. Marlowe walks on.

dialogues.speaker: PLYMOUTH COUPE
dialogues.text: the same car which was following Marlowe yesterday. Marlo passing, recognizes it, pauses, thoughtful, walks on.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: as he passes the mouth of a narrow alley two men step out quickly. One of them saps Marlowe expertly -- they drag him out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe is dazed, but not out. He fights, but the two boy give him an expert going-over, very quickly and efficient Marlowe goes down onto the wet bricks. One of the men lea over him.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: (gently) This is just our way of saying -- lay off. Get it, Marlowe? Lay off. He boots Marlowe in the stomach -- the pair of them depar while Marlowe is getting rid of his breakfast. Presently, while Marlowe is trying unsuccessfully to stand up, HARRY JONES comes up to him. Harry is small, hardly five feet, in a cheap snappy 'underworld' suit. Yet in his wizened ugly face there is independence, honesty, reliability, courage. He helps Marlowe to his feet, steadies him, hand him a handkerchief.  133. 120.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (still groggy -- wiping his face) You're the guy that's been tailing me.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Yeah. The name's Jones. Harry Jones. I want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's swell. Did you want to see those two guys jump me?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: I didn't care one way or the other.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You could have yelled for help.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: A guy's playing a hand, I let him play it. I'm no kibitzer.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (grinning) You got brains. Come on up to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe removes his coat and hat, hangs them up. Jones watches him. Marlowe is reasonably steady now, gradually getting his wind back.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Might as wall take yours off too. We may be here a good while, unless I get another case. He goes to the desk, sits down, lights a cigarette, pours stiff shot from the office bottle, then starts to riffle through a small stack of mail on his desk. Jones watches him. He opens top letter, reads it.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: I been around too. Used to runa little liquor. Rode the scout car with a Tommy gun in my lap. A tough racket.  121.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (reading, squinting through smoke) Terrible. He tosses the letter into wastebasket, takes up the next, opens it, sees Jones still standing.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Sit down. You make me nervous standing there. Jones sits on edge of a chair; Marlowe opens and rapidly reads the next letter, tosses it in wastebasket, opens the next one. Jones watches him.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Maybe you don't believe me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (throws letter into wastebasket) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (approvingly, man to man fashion) That's better. I got something to sell -- cheap, for a couple of C's.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (opens next letter) Then don't let me stop you.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (baffled) Don't you even want to know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (rapidly reading letter) I already know. You're not a cop. You don't belong to Eddie Mars, because I asked him. (throws last letter into wastebasket, sits back and looks at Jones) So Agnes is loose again, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (taken aback) How'd you know?  122.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Well -- she's a blonde.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: She's a nice girl. We're talking of getting married.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: She's too big for you. She'll roll on you and smother you.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (injured) That's a dirty crack, brother.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're right. I've been running around with the wrong people lately. Let's cut out the babble. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: You're looking for something. Will you pay for it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: If it does what?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Helps you find Regan.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Is that what you want the two C's for -- for telling me I'm looking for Regan? People have been telling me that for two days now. I don't even give cigars for it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (patiently) Do you want to know what I got, or don't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Two C's buys a lot of information in my circle.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Would you pay two hundred dollars to know where Eddie Mars' wife is? Would you pay two hundred bucks for that, shamus?  123.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (leans forward and rubs out cigarette) I think I would. Where?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Agnes found her. She'll tell you -- when she has the money in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You might tell the coppers for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (quietly) I ain't so brittle.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (speculatively) Agnes must have something I didn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (quietly, with dignity even) I ain't tried to pull anything. I come here with a straight proposition -- take it or leave it; one right guy to another. Then you start waving cops at me. You ought to be ashamed of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (quietly too) I am -- Okay. Two hundred it is. I'll have to go to the bank

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (rises) Okay. After dark'll be better anyway. You know Puss Walgreen's office -- Fulwider building -- four-twenty-eight at the back?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I can find it.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: I'll meet you there at seven o'clock tonight. You bring the money, and I'll take you to Agnes. Okay?  134. 135. 136. 137. 138. 124.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (going out) So long then. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING
dialogues.text: Marlowe enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is deserted. Marlowe pauses at elevator, the door is open, a shabby old man is asleep on the stool. Marlowe goes on.

dialogues.speaker: AT FIRE DOOR
dialogues.text: pushes the door open, enters stairs, door closes behind h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: standing flattened against the wall beside a door lettere

dialogues.speaker: L.D. WALGREEN
dialogues.text: The transom above it is open, light shines through.

dialogues.speaker: JONES' VOICE
dialogues.text: (beyond transom) Canino? Yeah, I've seen you around. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (purring) I thought you'd remember. Marlowe steals quietly back along the wall, reaches anoth door, pushes it quietly. It is locked. He takes out his wallet, removes his driver's license from its celluloid, takes the envelope and slips back the door-lock, opens th door carefully and quietly, enters, shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he stands beside an inner door which is slightly open, light burning beyond it. Through the crack in the door Harry Jones can be seen, sitting behind a shabby desk. Th other man, CANINO, is not in sight at this angle.  125. Jones is sweating; he cannot help that. But there is no fear in his voice and he is not trembling either.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: So you go to see this peeper, this Marlowe. That was your mistake. Eddie don't like it. And what Eddie don't like ain't healthy.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: You know why I went to the peeper. Account of Joe Brody's girl. She's got to blow. That takes dough. She figured the peeper could get it for her.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Dough for what?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: You know about the night the kid bumped Brody? Well, the young Sternwood girl was there. She not only dropped in, she took a shot at Brody. Only the peeper didn't tell the cops that. So Agnes figures it's railroad fare for her as soon as she can get hold of the peeper. You get it?

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Where's this Agnes?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: What do you care? All she wants is to touch the peeper and blow -- His voice stops. He sits back, staring Canino off, shows terror now despite himself, but still no fear.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (purring) That's right. Look at it. You'll tell me, little man. Where's Agnes?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: Listen --

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You want me to count three or something, like a movie? Where's Agnes?  139. 126.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (gives in, collapses) You win. She's in an apartment at 28 Court. Apartment 501. I guess I'm yellow, all right.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You just got good sense. I ain't going to hurt her. If everything's like you say, I'll tell Eddie it's all jakeloo. We'll even dip the bill on it. As Canino's hand comes into sight setting a whiskey bottle on the desk, Marlowe steps quickly back.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Got a glass?

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: (stares at the bottle, hopeless now, sweating but still bravely) There at the cooler. As Canino enters, Marlowe steps quickly out. Canino crosses the open door. We now SEE HIM; a stocky, vicious man in brown: a killer.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE FLATTENED AGAINST THE WALL
dialogues.text: beside the door. Jones cannot be seen now, only Canino as he takes the glass from water cooler and crosses the door again. Now he too is not visible. Marlowe follows him by SOUND ALONE as he returns to the table, clinks the bottle against the glass as he pours the drink.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (purring, falsely hearty) There you are. Drink her down. Mud in your eye. Jones' breathing can be heard as he pants. When Canino speaks next, his voice is a little sharper.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Drink it. What do you think it is -- poison? I bet that Agnes of yours wouldn't turn it down.  140. 141. 127.

dialogues.speaker: JONES
dialogues.text: No. (SOUND of his movement as he takes the glass) Success.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Lots of it. SOUND as Jones drinks, dies, the glass CLINKS as he drops it, his body thuds as he falls forward, gasps, chokes. Marlowe starts forward, catches himself. The other room goes dark. SOUND as Canino leaves it: his feet, the other door opens, closes again.

dialogues.speaker: GLASS DOOR
dialogues.text: The door opens on the corridor. With the light gone, the glass in the door is faintly luminous, lettering in reverse, Canino's shadow across it. SOUND of his feet die away. Marlowe moves swiftly toward the inner door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his hand on the switch as he turns on the light, looks fo an instant at Jones sprawled dead across the desk, the whiskey bottle and overturned glass beside him. Marlowe pauses only a second. He looks about, sees what he wants, crosses to telephone, takes it up, dials hurriedly.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Information, can you give me the phone number of Apartment 301, 28 Court Street? (he lowers phone, waits, raises phone quickly again, listens attentively) Thanks. (puts phone down, takes it up again, dials) Is Agnes in? The VOICE that answers is a MAN'S VOICE, burly and loud, that it can be heard over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: No Agnes here, buddy. what number you want?  128.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Wentworth two-five-two-eight.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Right number, wrong gal. Ain't it a shame!

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Can you put me back on to the switchboard?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Here you go. (phone clicks, whirrs)

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hello, Manager? This is Wallis, Police Identification Bureau, is there a girl named Agnes Lozelle registered at your place?... Well, have you got a tall blonde with green eyes, either alone, or witha little chap that weighs about a hundred pounds, green hat, gray overcoat... Yeah, must have been the wrong address. Thanks. He puts the phone down, turns, looks at Jones.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (musing aloud, with admiration) Well, you died like a poisoned rat. But you drank your poison like a man before you split on your girl, didn't you? He approaches, gingerly and carefully shifts Jones enough to reach inside his coat, is about to search Jones, the telephone rings. Marlowe pauses, thinks, makes decision, takes up phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yeah?... Hello, Agnes... Marlowe, the guy you want to see. No, he's not here. He's gone, beat it. But I've got the money. Where are you?... I don't know where he went. Do you want the two C's or don't you?... In half an hour. Right.  142. 143. 129. He puts the phone down, takes out his handkerchief and wipes his fingerprints off of it, crosses to the light switch, wipes it off too, turns it with the handkerchief, goes to the door, through which he came, exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he wipes off the knob with his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe gets into the car -- the gray Plymouth. Beyond the rain-streaked windows a Los Angeles street is visible lighted store windows, etc.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: I thought you were never coming. Give me the money. Marlowe hands her folded bills. She counts them rapidly b the dash light, then puts them in her handbag.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: This is a getaway stake, copper. I'm on my way. What happened to Harry?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I told you he ran away. Canino got wise to him somehow. Forget Harry. I've paid for information and I want it.

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: You'll get it. Joe and I were out riding Foothill Boulevard a couple weeks ago. We passed a brown coupe, and I saw the girl who was driving. She was Eddie Mars' wife. There was a guy with her -- the watchdog, Canino. They're people you don't forget, even if you only saw them once. So we got curious, and Joe tailed them. About a mile east of Realito there's a side road, and nothing around it but brush and hills. Just off the highway there's a two-bit garage and paintshop run by a guy named Art Huck -- hot car drop, likely -- and a frame house behind it. That's where Eddie Mars' wife is holed up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (studying her coldly) You're sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: AGNES
dialogues.text: Why should I lie?... Well, goodbye, copper -- wish me luck. I got a raw deal.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Your kind always does. He turns and opens the door to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Illuminated by the spotlight of a car. Above a black arro the sign says:

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (RAIN)
dialogues.text: Marlowe's car spinning along at high speed. The highway runs between miles of orange groves, with mountains in th b.g.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Orange groves -- a neon sign: WELCOME TO REALITO -- small lighted store fronts -- a bar -- a theatre -- then dark barren fields.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (RAIN)
dialogues.text: Marlowe's car rushing along the wet highway, which now ru through barren country close to the foothills. The car takes an S curve, skidding dangerously.

dialogues.speaker: ON MARLOWE'S CAR
dialogues.text: as it swings into another curve, a sharp one, and deliberately skids off the shoulder, jarring finally toa stop in the ditch.  149. 150. 151. 152. 153. 154. 155. 156. 157. 131.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: as he climbs out and bends to inspect the tires. It is raining heavily.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: as he lets the air out of the two right-hand tires.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: as he straightens up and looks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE'S ANGLE
dialogues.text: A SMALL DINGY GARAGE, with a frame house behind it. Light show dimly through shaded windows.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: as he nods, satisfied, then gets back into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe takes the license holder from the steering post a puts it in his pocket, then leans lower behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT OF THE CAR SEAT
dialogues.text: as Marlowe's hand pushes open a weighted flap, disclosing secret compartment with two guns in it. He weighs them, selects the heavier of the two, and draws it out. The fla swings shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe approaches the garage. There is a sign on the blank side wall -- Marlowe holds a flashlight on it, and SEE the lettering of the sign:

dialogues.speaker: AUTO REPAIRS
dialogues.text: Marlowe goes round to the front. The big doors are closed but a streak of light shows through the crack. Marlowe hesitates, then walks past them to glance at the house.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (RAIN)
dialogues.text: The only signs of life are the light from the shaded windows and Canino's brown coupe parked in front by a row of stunted trees.  158. 159. 132.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door, as Marlowe goes up and hammers on it with th butt of his heavy flashlight. There is a moment of silence. Then the inside light goes off. Marlowe centers his flash in a white circle of light on the doors.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: (speaking through the door) Whaddaya want?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Open up, I got two flats back on the highway and only one spare.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: Sorry, mister. We're closed up. Better try Realito. Marlowe doesn't appreciate this. He kicks the door, hard, and keeps on kicking it, until a second voice -- Canino's voice -- speaks from close inside. Then he stops to listen.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Okay, Art -- open up for the wise guy. A BOLT SQUEALS, and half the door opens inward. Marlowe's flash outlines a gaunt hard face, Huck's face. Then Huck swings a gun down across the flash, knocking it out of Marlowe's hand, still burning.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: Kill that spot, bud. Marlowe picks up the flash, turning it off. Light goes on inside the garage, revealing HUCK, a tall man in dirty coveralls. He backs away from the door, keeping Marlowe covered.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: Come inside and shut the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe closes the door behind him. There is the usual paraphernalia of a garage, and two cars. One is being painted, a spray-gun lying on the fender, the other is Carmen Sternwood's Packard convertible. Canino lounges easily in the shadows by the bench. The RAIN BEATS on the tin roof.  133.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (indicating Huck's gun) You could scare off a lot of trade that way.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: I'm too far out of town to take chances. (pointedly) You can get yourself hurt, kicking on doors.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: (softly) Cut it out, Art. You run a garage, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (not looking at Canino) Thanks. (to Huck) I suppose you can fix flats.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: (putting the gun in his pocket) As good as you can make ‘em, bud. But right now I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Art -- you got time to fix his tires.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You can use my spare -- that'll help some.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: Listen, I told you I'm busy with a spray job...

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: It's too damp for a good spray job, Art. Get moving -- and take two jacks.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute... Canino looks at Huck with a soft quiet-eyed stare, then away again, not saying anything. Huck wilts and moves pulling on a raincoat and banging out with a socket wrench, a hand jack, and wheeling a dolly.  160. 134. Canino closes the door behind him and returns to the workbench. Marlowe watches silently, lighting a cigarette

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: Bet you could use a drink. Wet the inside, and even up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks. Canino produces a bottle and two glasses from under the bench, pours two shots, and hands one to Marlowe. They salute -- Canino drinks, and Marlowe, remembering Harry Jones and the cyanide cocktail, hesitates, then drinks also.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: (casually) Live around here?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. Just got in from Reno and Carson City.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: The long way round, huh? Business trip?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Partly. And in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: Too bad -- you may have a long wait. (reaching for Marlowe's empty glass) How about another, to pass the time.

dialogues.speaker: A WHEEL
dialogues.text: -- the tire already on a spreader and loose from the rim. A man's hands and feet working at the job viciously. The CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Art Huck as he rips out the tub Marlowe and Canino stand almost as before, by the workbench.

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: (grumbling over above action) I don't have enough to do -- guys have to get flats in the middle of a cloudburst.  161. 135.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: (laughing) Don't crab so much. You can use an extra bath. (taking a roll of coins out of his pocket, tossing them idly in the palm of his hand) Just get busy. Huck carries the tube to an airhose and starts to fill it

dialogues.speaker: HUCK
dialogues.text: I am busy, brother. Plenty busy. He starts to place the tube in the galvanized tub under t hose, then turns swiftly, lifting the tube high, and brin it down over Marlowe's head and shoulders, a perfect ringer. Marlowe, unable to reach the gun in his pocket, bends forward, trying to throw Huck over his back. Canino steps in lightly, like a dancer, his hand closed hard ove the roll of coins, and hangs one with delicate precision Marlowe's jaw. Marlowe's tough -- he goes on fighting, although he's already out on his feet. Huck pulls his head back by the hair as Canino clips him again with the weighted fist. Marlowe tries, but it's no use. He goes down and stays that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room, in keeping with the exterior -- furnished comfortably but not luxuriously. The only light comes fro a floor lamp beside the davenport where Marlowe lies. His hands are cuffed behind him, his feet roped to the leg of the davenport. He is still out, his face considerably the worse for wear. Vivian sits beside him on a straight chair, holding a half empty glass in her hand. She seems to have forgotten about it. She seems to have forgotten everything but Marlowe -- who begins to come out of it. H opens his eyes presently and looks at Vivian -- he doesn' seem surprised. He winces and shuts his eyes again.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (thickly) Move the light, honey... Vivian rises and turns the light away from his face. He looks up at her again.  136.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (still groggy) That's better -- where are the boys -- out digging a grave?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (desperately) Phil, why did you have to go on with this?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why did you? Vivian turns away from him -- she's obviously keyed up, scared, desperate.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I've only known one fool as big as you...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) You might spare me a little of that drink you're not using. Vivian goes to him, sits down, and holds the glass to Marlowe's lips, then touches his battered face with her fingertips.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (shakily) Your face looks like a collision met...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It won't last long, even this good. (after a pause, looking up at Vivian softly) I'll give it back to you -- I've only known one fool as big as you. They hold it, a twisted uncomfortable moment, and then MO MARS enters. She is tall, blonde, strikingly beautiful -- a woman who knows her way around, yet having a certain dignity and fineness.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You would be Mrs. Eddie Mars... the blond that Shawn Regan didn't run away with.  137.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Why did you have to make trouble? Eddie wasn't doing you any harm. I was never in love with Shawn -- we were just good friends. But you know perfectly well that if I hadn't hid out here when Shawn disappeared, the police would have been certain Eddie killed him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (quietly) But he did kill him.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (after a pause, with quiet dignity) Eddie's not that sort of man.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You mean Eddie never kills people.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You really believe that, don't you? And in a way, I suppose you're right...

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (sincerely) I'm married to Eddie Mars. I love him. I know what's inside of him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Well, if Eddie's such a nice guy, I'd like to talk to him without Canino around. You know what Canino will do -- beat my teeth out and then kick me in the stomach for mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You'll get your talk, Phil. Canino's gone for Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Leaving Art Huck within call, I suppose. Well, I suppose nobody's luck holds forever. (to Vivian) You could really have gone to Mexico, you know. You'd have liked it better. Blood doesn't spatter that far.  138.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Oh, stop talking that way! Vivian and Marlowe are no longer conscious of her presenc having retired into a private world of their own.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: But then you couldn't go, could you. The border police would have checked you through alone, and too many people might have seen you -- without Shawn Regan. Much safer to come down here with Mona. Much safer -- especially for Eddie Mars.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I did it as much for you... Why wouldn't you believe me? Why wouldn't you stop?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Too many people tried to make me. And besides I knew Shawn Regan -- and I know you. They look at each other -- and Mona Mars takes herself quietly out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Why did I have to meet you? Why out of all the men in the city, did my father have to call you in?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Things happen that way, sometimes... Light me a cigarette... She takes one from a table, lights it, and bends over to place it between Marlowe's lips. Marlowe's eyes hold her as though his hands were on her shoulders; she sits down.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (softly) You know what they're going to do, don't you? You know the only thing they can do. Vivian's hands grip the shoulders of his coat. She shuts her eyes and drops her head, holding herself rigid.  139.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (still softly) It's not pretty, is it -- even from a distance. And when you're right on top of it, it isn't pretty at all.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (rising abruptly) Oh, stop it, Phil. Stop it! Nothing's going to happen...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Mona's in love with Eddie Mars, but you're not. Are you going through with it? Vivian moves away, as far from him as she can get, and stands with her back to him, rigid, staring at the curtained window as though she could see through it. Marlowe studies her, then laughs, a quiet sardonic chuckl and relaxes, leaning back on the cushion.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Pride is a great thing, isn't it? And courage -- and honor -- and love. All the things you read about in the copybooks -- only in the copybooks nothing ever gets tangled. The road always lies so straight, and clear, and the signs say to love and honor and be brave... Take this thing out of my mouth, will you, honey? It's burning me. Vivian comes slowly to him and takes the cigarette stub from his lips. She hesitates, then goes down onto the couch, dropping the cigarette on the floor. Her arms go around Marlowe, her mouth crushed to his. When she breaks for air, putting her cheek against his, she is almost crying. Marlowe is far from unmoved himself, turning his head against hers, hard.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (after a pause, whispering) Get a knife, and cut this rope off me... Vivian rises, runs out of the room. The SOUND of a kitche drawer being opened comes OVER from o.s., then the RATTLE of CUTLERY. Vivian returns almost at once with a knife an slashes the rope from Marlowe's feet. Dropping the knife, she helps him get up -- he's not too steady on his legs. They cross the room together, Vivian with her arm around Marlowe. The handcuffs glittering on Marlowe's wrists.  162. 140. From outside comes the SOUND of a car skidding to a stop. Mona Mars appears in the doorway, holding a gun.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (quietly, without menace) Eddie is here -- I think you'd better wait.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO'S HAND
dialogues.text: opening, playing idly with the roll of coins. The CAMERA PULLS BACK -- we are still in the living room. Marlowe is sitting on the couch, Vivian beside him -- his hands are still cuffed behind him, but his feet are free. Canino leans unobtrusively against the wall -- near Marlowe. Eddie Mars holds center stage, moving like a lio keyed up for the kill. Mona Mars, the gun forgotten in he hand, sits in the b.g., watching. Her face is still, intent.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (quietly) Eddie -- this is where I get off.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: You bought a ticket for the whole run, Countess -- destination unknown. Keep your mouth out of this. (to Marlowe) You're making it tough for me, soldier.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not me, Eddie. Murder. Murder can make things tough for anybody. You keep tripping over it, all the time.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) Murder! I haven't killed anybody.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not personally, maybe -- but your hand is behind Canino's, aiming the gun -- or pouring the cyanide into Harry Jones' glass. (as Mars gives him a startled look) Yeah -- I was there, in the next room. Canino had a gun and I didn't, so all I could do was watch... I kind of liked Harry Jones.  141.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: You kind of like too many people, soldier.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Eddie -- what does he mean? What's happened? Who was Harry Jones?

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: He's just talking. Maybe you better get out, Mona. We may have to push him around a little before we get through.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (to Mona) Yeah -- push me a little, right over the edge. Eddie won't spoil his manicure to do it -- but Canino won't mind. He's used to having his hands dirty. Canino leans over and slaps Marlowe hard across the face. Vivian springs up, toward Canino -- Eddie Mars grabs her, looking toward Mona. Mona has never seen that look on Eddie's face before.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (quietly) Get out, Mona.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Eddie...

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Get out. Mona studies him -- it seems that she is looking at a stranger, a stranger who frightens her, someone evil and beyond the pale. She seems to grow in stature and dignity even as her heart realizes how far down the wrong road it has traveled. She turns, then, slowly, and goes out. After she has gone, Vivian wrenches free from Mars' grip. There is something rather wonderful about her now -- a blazing, catlike courage. She faces Eddie Mars.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You don't dare go through with this, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: You think I can't get away with it?  142.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You think I'm going to let you get away with it? Mars studies her, then Marlowe -- realizes what the score is, and smiles sardonically.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: You women kill me. You'll spend years and wreck lives to get something you want, and then throw it all away in a minute because some guy has a new way of putting his mouth on yours. (sitting down, easily, smiling) All right, Countess. While we're doing all this thinking... do you think you're going to have a chance not to let me get away with it? Silence as this sinks in. Vivian sits down quietly beside Marlowe, who looks at both her and Mars with a cold, cynical smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (laughing softly) It's amazing how fast a beautiful friendship breaks when a dead body falls on top of it... Which one of you killed Regan? If he was shot in the back, I'll bet on you, Eddie, because that's the only way you could have got to him. But if he took it from the front -- (looking at Vivian) I can see how you both would have been jealous of Mona. Vivian stares at him, a hard, shocked look as though Marlowe is something not human. Marlowe gives it back to her -- then almost at once Canino steps forward and place his hand on Marlowe's head, bending it back, his fingers and thumb biting cruelly into Marlowe's temples. Canino smiles, as though he is very fond of Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: (gently amused) Ever see a dick with such a one-track mind? He's sitting right on the edge of a hole in the ground, but he still cares who killed Regan. Want to tell him, Eddie? Want to send him to bed happy?  163. 143. Mars makes an annoyed gesture and starts to get up, then freezes as Mona speaks from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (very quietly) Eddie... Everyone turns to look at her -- there is a quality of fa in her voice. She leans almost negligently against the door jamb, wearing a heavy coat, holding a big felt hat i her hands.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I've been a good wife to you, Eddie -- as good a wife as you'd let me be. I believed in you, and there wasn't anything I wouldn't have done for you -- anything but this.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: Don't be a fool, Mona. Can't you see...

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: (slowly) I can only see one thing. I've been Married to a killer, and I've helped him kill. She turns and goes out. Mars rises, looking after her.

dialogues.speaker: MARS
dialogues.text: (to Canino) Hold the fort, Canino. I'1l be back. He goes out after Mona, not even waiting for Canino's nod of assent. Canino goes to a window and peers through the crack of the blind, still keeping Marlowe covered. We HEA a car start outside and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: (sardonically) He made it. And he can talk about love. He turns back into the room. Vivian has risen, she stands by a table lighting a cigarette with a wooden match from box which she retains in her left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ordinary small box of matches. The cover has been pushed almost shut, leaving the head of one match protruding.  164. 165. 166. 167.
Vivian holds the flaming match with which she has just lighted her cigarette to the uncovered match head, igniting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Vivian blows out the first match and drops it casually into an ash tray, shielding the box in her hand from Canino's view. Canino strolls back, looking Marlowe over with sadistic humor.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: I don't really mind the boss leaving. I can have a lot more fun alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The match has burned back, charring the paper cover. Smok rises from the box.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Canino --

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: (looking around, grinning) Save your breath, baby -- The match box bursts into flame. Vivian hurls it into Canino's face, then turns aside, clutching her scorched fingers.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (over above action) Phil! Marlowe throws himself forward into Canino's legs -- they roll, struggling.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE AND CANINO
dialogues.text: as Canino comes out on top of Marlowe, at an angle, and whips his pistol down at Marlowe's head. Marlowe wrenches aside -- the gun barrel misses by a fraction, smacking ha on the carpet. Marlowe doubles his knees into his chest and lets go with his feet, getting both heels under Canino's jaw. Canino goes backward and down, dropping his gun, but he's not clear out -- the blow was glancing. He grabs Vivian as she tries to get by him, pulling her down Marlowe manages to get the gun in his shackled hands. Canino pulls another, fires at him, misses, tangled up wi Vivian. Marlowe makes it out the door.  168. 169. 170. 145.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Marlowe comes out and runs down the steps toward Canino's car. Over by the garage Art Huck stands, scared but undecided. Marlowe snaps a shot at him. Huck makes up his mind in a hurry. He vanishes -- a second later we HEA a car start and race off down the highway, 0.s. Marlowe, working fast but awkwardly because of the handcuffs, open the door of Canino's car, backs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: fumbling for the ignition key and starter button, behind him. He starts the motor, then slides out again, quickly, hugging the ground by the rear wheels, offside.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT, (RAIN)
dialogues.text: As a darkened window goes up. THREE SHOTS are fired from it. We HEAR the whine of the bullets, their impact on the coupe. Marlowe cries out as though hit. Then again there is silence, except for the beating rain and the purring motor. Presently the house door opens -- there is no light behin it. Vivian appears, walking stiffly, and behind her is Canino, shielded from possible fire. They walk slowly toward Marlowe and the car.

dialogues.speaker: CANINO
dialogues.text: Can you see anything?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (tonelessly) Nothing. The windows are all misted. They come steadily closer to the dark car. Suddenly Vivia stops, rigid, and lets go a thin, tearing scream.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Behind the wheel! (as though pleading with Marlowe not to fire) Phil! Canino shoves her roughly aside, dropping to one knee, an pours three SHOTS through the car window. His gun is now empty. No shots answer him -- he is satisfied that Marlow is dead. He rises, moving to open the car door, as Marlow emerges from behind the car.  171. 146.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Finished? Canino whirls around, and Marlowe, the gun pressed awkwardly against his side, puts four bullets in him. He collapses into the mud and stays there.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (to Vivian) Get the keys, honey. Vivian, white-faced and silent, gets the keys from Canino pocket and unlocks the handcuffs. Marlowe rubs his wrists -- they look at each other, both tired and drained of emotion -- there seems to be nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (quietly) You played that hand all right, Countess.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (dully) I don't know why I cared. She turns and walks away from him toward the garage and h car, not looking back. Presently Marlowe goes back into the house. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Norris stands in the open door, in the act of admittin Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: The General sent for me...

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He's waiting, in the orchid house. Marlowe enters, walking along the hall toward the rear wi Norris. Subtly, Norris has the air of a guard. Marlowe looks tired and somber, the marks of last night's encount still plain on his face. He has obviously not been home; he wears the same rumpled suit, no tie, and he has not shaved. Vivian comes out of an adjoining room, as though she has been waiting, and stops them.  172. 147.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I'd like to see you, Mr. Marlowe. She gives Norris the nod -- he goes away, and Marlowe follows Vivian into the room, closing the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lavishly furnished. Vivian also looks exhausted, stony, but giving an impression of submerged but volcanic emotio She does not look at Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I kept you out of it. I tolda straight story, and Canino left his thumbprint on Harry Jones' door to back me up. I don't know whether they believed me, but there's nothing they can do about it. I'm clear -- self defense. And all Eddie Mars has to say is that Canino was roughing me on his own time.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (looking at him now, forced to admire him) It wasn't as easy as you make it sound.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (shrugging) My neck is usually stuck out, one way or another. It's a little tougher than the General's, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (after an uncomfortable pause) It's too bad Father can't know what you've done for him. I'm afraid he's... angry with you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why not? Everybody else is.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You -- won't say anything to him?  148.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Phil...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (brutally) Listen... I'm tired. I killeda man last night. I stink of cops, and I've still got a rotten taste in my mouth. I want a hot bath with strong soap, and I can't have it until I've seen your father. Do you mind if I go now?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (going close to him) Phil -- I didn't kill Shawn Regan.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (cold, deadpan) Is he dead? Vivian stares at him, getting a slow, deadly look in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (very calmly) It's quite possible. He's been gone a long time, and he's not a peaceful man. (turning away) I'll send you my personal check in the morning, Mr. Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Your personal check?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I'm sure my father would wish you to be repaid for your... extra services, last night.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (quietly, after pause) I'm sure your father would know better... and I know you do -- What about Eddie Mars?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: What about him?  173. 174. 149.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You think he's going to forget all this?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I'm tired, too. Get out, Marlowe. Marlowe shrugs, goes toward the door. He speaks over his shoulder with an air of casual politeness.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How's Carmen? Vivian, her back to him, takes the question just a little too easily.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: She's fine. She went up to Santa Barbara last night.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That ought to be nice for her.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Yes. There seems to be nothing more to say. Marlowe exits.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. STERNWOOD REAR GARDEN’ - DAY - MARLOWE AND NORRIS as they walk down the path toward the orchid house. Marlowe glances around, apparently looking for something doesn't see. Norris opens the door, permitting Marlowe to pass him into the greenhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he follows the path between the banks of orchids to th place where General Sternwood sits, as before -- in the wheelchair, wrapped in robe and blanket -- only his eyes are alive, proud and piercing.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Sit down, Mr. Marlowe. Marlowe pulls up a chair, already beginning to suffer wit the heat. He starts to remove his coat, then something in Sternwood's attitude makes him change his mind.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: I didn't ask you to look for Shawn Regan.  150.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You wanted me to, though.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: You assume a great deal. I usually ask for what I want. (as Marlowe does not answer) The money I paid you is of no consequence. I merely feel that you have, no doubt unintentionally, betrayed a trust.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Is that all you wanted to see me about?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: You're angry at that remark.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You have an advantage over me, General. It's an advantage I wouldn't want to take away from you. You can say anything you like to me, and I wouldn't think of getting angry. I'd like to offer you your money back. It may mean nothing to you. It might mean something to me.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: What does it mean to you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It means I've refused payment for an unsatisfactory job. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Why did you go to Captain Gregory?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I suppose I played a hunch. I was convinced you put those Geiger notes up to me chiefly as a test, and that you were a little afraid Regan might somehow be involved in an attempt to blackmail you. Besides, as I said -- I knew Regan. It meant something to me to find out, too.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: And you allowed Captain Gregory to think I had employed you to find Shawn?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess I did -- when I was sure he had the case.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: And do you consider that ethical?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Perhaps I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Maybe you don't. When you hire a boy in my line of work it isn't like hiring a window-washer and showing him eight windows and saying: "Wash those windows and you're through." You don't know what I have to go through or over or under to do your job for you. I do it my way. I do my best to protect you, and I may have to break a few rules, but I break them in your favor -- After all, you didn't tell me NOT to go to Captain Gregory.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (with a faint smile) That would have been rather difficult.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Well, what have I done wrong? Your man Norris, seemed to think the case was over when Geiger was eliminated. I don't see it that way. I'm not Sherlock Holmes. I don't expect to go over ground the police have covered and pick up a broken penpoint and build a case from it. If you think there's anybody in the detective business making a living doing that sort of thing, you don't know much about cops. If they overlook anything, it's something much looser and vaguer, like a man of Geiger's type sending you his evidence of debt and asking you to pay like a gentleman. That isn't normal. Why did he do that? Because he wanted to find out if there was anything putting pressure (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: on you. If there was, you'd pay him. If not, you'd ignore him and wait. But something was putting pressure on you. Regan. You were afraid he'd stayed around and been nice to you just long enough to find out how to play games with your bank account. (interrupting Sternwood, as he starts to speak) Even at that, it wasn't your money you cared about. It wasn't even your daughters. You've more or less written them off. It's that you're still too proud to be played for a sucker -- and you really liked Shawn Regan.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (quietly, after a pause) You think entirely too much, Marlowe -- Are you still trying to solve that puzzle?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. I've been warned to quit. The boys at the City Hall think I play too rough. That's why I thought I should give you your money back -- because it isn't a completed job by my standards.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (smiling) Quit, nothing. I'll pay you another thousand to find Shawn Regan. He doesn't have to come back. I don't even have to know where he is. A man has a right to live his own life. And he must have had his reasons for running off like that. I only want to know that he's all right. I want to know it from him directly, and if he should happen to need money, I should want him to have that also. Am I clear?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yes, General. Sternwood leans back in the chair, his eyes closed wearil  175. 153.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (trying to smile) I guess I'm a sentimental old goat, and no soldier at all. Find him for me, Marlowe. Just find him.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (rising) I'll try. You'd better rest now. I've talked your arm off. He starts away. Sternwood's voice stops him.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: (quietly) You have a lot that Shawn had. Strength -- and a steady eye. Marlowe stands a moment, remembering Vivian's words. Then he turns quietly and goes away.

dialogues.speaker: GREENHOUSE DOOR
dialogues.text: as he emerges, mopping again, finds Norris waiting for hi already holding Marlowe's hat for him. Marlowe, surprised at this, is still further surprised when he looks up and sees his car, which he left in front of the house, now in the drive not far away and already turned so that it is headed back toward town.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: I took the liberty of turning it around for you, sir. Since you were in the greenhouse, I brought it on around here at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (ironically) So that now I won't lose hardly any time getting back to work, huh?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (impenetrable) You will always be welcome here, sir, if only to receive our gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (stuffs handkerchief into pocket, takes his hat, turns) Thanks.  154. He walks toward the car. But still Norris walks beside him. Marlowe already realizing that he is being practically frog-walked off the place. They reach the car Norris steps ahead, opens the door, holds it open for Marlowe to get in.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You don't even need a gun, do you?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: I've never had occasion for one, sir. I don't think I ever will.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Neither do I. (nods toward greenhouse) What do you think of him this morning?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: He's stronger than he looks. As you would see for yourself if occasion arose -- which, thanks to you, it will not now.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- what did Regan have that got to the General so?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Youth, sir. And the soldier's eye.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Like yours.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. And yours.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Thanks. (he starts to get into the car, Norris still holding the door) So Miss Carmen went to Santa Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: Yes. This morning.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (getting into car, stops) Mrs. Rutledge told me she went last night.  176. 177. 155.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (smoothly) It was near midnight, sir. I thought it was later. I was probably wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I see. He gets in. Norris shuts the door. Marlowe starts the engine, puts car in gear.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: If the General has any more trouble, you know how to call.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: And whom to call. Thank you again. Marlowe drives on. In the mirror he can see Norris standing in the drive still watching him, guarding the house which Marlowe realizes he is not to enter again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe has just entered. He kicks the door shut, crosses the living room, shedding his hat and suit coat on the floor as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe continues on his way to the bath, still peelin He vanishes into the bath -- we HEAR the shower turned on In the bedroom the PHONE RINGS. Marlowe returns, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah? The voice of Eddie Mars comes clearly from the instrument

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello, soldier.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Hello, Eddie. I been waiting to hear from you.  178. 156.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Got a little news for you, soldier. I'm skipping the manicures, till I finish up this job.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I kind of thought you would. I got a T.L. for you, too, Eddie. Sternwood offered me a thousand bucks to find Shawn Regan. I took it.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: (softly, after a pause) Maybe I can help you earn that grand. You remember that stuff that Joe Brody moved out of Geiger's back room?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Well, I tracked it down where Joe stashed it, and moved it back up to Geiger's place after the cops got through. You might take a look at it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I might.

dialogues.speaker: MARS' VOICE
dialogues.text: (laughing softly) After last night I'm beginning to think you're as tough as you look. I told you we could do business together. So long, soldier.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Be seeing you. The receiver clicks. Marlowe sets his instrument down slowly, looks at it a moment, then returns to the shower dropping his shirt in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe comes out of the bath, buttoning his pajama coat. He is freshly shaved, his hair still damp and rumpled from the shower. He pulls down the shades, puttin out the daylight, and collapses into the bed.  179. 157. Just as he is comfortably settled, already half asleep, t doorbell RINGS. It rings insistently, with a quality of nervous urgency. Marlowe finally gets up to answer it, pulling on a dressing gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe admits Vivian. She is obviously in a fine stat of nerves. She enters quickly -- he shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Phil...

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: All right, now what?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Eddie Mars just called me. He's out to get you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: We knew that a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: But now you must believe it. You must get out of town -- now.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You better sit down, baby, and catch your breath. He sits down on the davenport.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Phil, how do you feel about me?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Just like I feel about a stick of dynamite. Smooth on the outside -- but it makes a mess when it goes off.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I got a different idea last night. Or maybe you're not a man except when two or three people are trying to murder you. They kiss -- one of those kisses. Vivian frees herself.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Now go. At once. I'll give you Money -- a thousand -- five thousand if you'll get out of town now -- today...  158.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That would be stage money. I like to earn my money. I can't earn that much at one time, but what I do earn doesn't smell bad to me.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Would you get out of town if you knew Shawn Regan was dead?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Is Shawn Regan dead?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Would you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How did he die?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Kiss me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Later -- maybe. How did Shawn die?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I killed him. By accident. He was teaching me to shoot and the gun went off.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And that's what Eddie Mars has got on you. And so he sent you here, to buy me off with you. Vivian stares at him, slaps him viciously across the face Marlowe takes it. She slaps

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Will you have the kiss now, too? him again. He takes it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're good, you're very good, but you can't do it, baby. It won't wash.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You fool, I killed him, I tell you. Just as you're going to be dead if you don't get out of town. Don't you see Eddie Mars can't let you stay alive now?  159.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Eddie never developed that trouble this morning. Now I'll ask you one. what's your game with me?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: There's no game -- with you.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You've been playing spin the bottle with me ever since I met you. It's "please, Phil' one minute, and ‘get out, Marlowe' the next. You haven't told me a straight truth since the first day...

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: That's a lie. I'm trying to play straight now. You fool, don't you realize you're going to die if you stay here?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. All you've told me is that you want me out of town at any price -- and that you still believe I can be bought if you can just find the right currency. Sure I'ma fool. I try to do my job and keep my nose clean. I risk my whole future, the hatred of the cops and Eddie Mars' gang. I dodge bullets and eat saps. But I'm not supposed to feel anything about it either way, because anybody can buy my immortal soul with a few bucks -- or maybe just a kiss. Sure, I'ma fool. She stares at him, her eyes blazing. Suddenly she raises her hand, but before she can slap him, he speaks and she pauses.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That's right. Have another. I throw them in free to old clients. She stops, stares at him, suddenly takes his face between her hands, stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: You're going to find Shawn Regan?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: No matter who gets hurt?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No matter who gets hurt.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (letting her hands drop to his shoulders) All right, Phil. It's funny -- I think I really like you now, for the first time. She turns to the door, her head high, her voice very cool and steady. Only her eyes, hidden from Marlowe, tell how she feels.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Phil. She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe comes out, wearing a hat and trench-coat again the rain which has begun to fall. He gets into his car an drives off. As he does so, a second car, a dark convertib seen indistinctly in the shadowy street, swings around th corner behind him, slows, falters, then picks up speed, following Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe drives slowly, cautiously toward Geiger's hous The street is dark, deserted. Marlowe drives without lights. He stops in the tree-shadows by the angle of Geiger's hedge and slides quietly out of the car, keeping close to the hedge. His gum gleams faintly in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A section of the road over which Marlowe has just come. The dark convertible creeps along in the shadows, also without lights. It is still impossible to see who is driving.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GEIGER'S PLACE
dialogues.text: as Marlowe makes his way like a stalking cat through the garden, toward the front door. Nothing stirs. There is no sound but the rain. Marlowe crosses the exposed bridge at a crouching run.  184. 185. 186. 187. 161. Nothing happens. He pauses in the shadows by the front do then tries the knob. Silently the door swings open. He waits, then darts swiftly inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark convertible, still shrouded in the heavy shadows of the trees, parks quietly behind Marlowe's car across t road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe stands beside the door, which he has closed, listening. He is only a shadow among shadows. The house is utterly still. Marlowe, still cautious, crosses into the rear part of the house, then returns.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (laughing softly) Okay, Eddie. I get it -- on the way out. He draws the heavy curtains quickly across the windows, turns on the lights and sheds his hat and coat. The packing box from Geiger's back room stands on the hearth- rug. Marlowe bends over to look inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: filled with manila filing envelopes, ledgers, etc. On the top of the stack is a folder labeled "Sternwood". It has obviously been placed there on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marlowe picks up the folder -- a KNOCK SOUNDS on the fron door. Marlowe reacts, dropping the folder, and raises his gun. He moves quickly to turn out the lights, then stands beside the door, flat against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Phil -- let me in.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (after a pause, unlocking the door) Come in fast and shut the door behind you.  162. He retains his wary position while Carmen obeys. When he is sure she's alone, he sighs, relocks the door and turns on the lights. His face is beaded with sweat, his hand shaking slightly. Carmen is lightly clad, without hat or coat. Apparently she has left home in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Did I scare you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (dryly) . . No -- I was expecting visitors... I thought you were in Santa Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: They had me locked in my room. They even had my clothes locked up. But I climbed down the drain pipe. I had to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why did you come here?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: You were just driving away when I got to your place. I followed. She is obviously wrought up, in a highly emotional state.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It must have been important.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: It was. Phil, I -- I'm sorry about the other night.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: I can't. Phil, you... I don't know quite how to say this... have you ever seen something, perhaps ina dream? Something perfect and beautiful, a long way off, and you try to reach it but there are too Many things in your way?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know what you mean.  163.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Maybe if everything had been different -- if I hadn't been born a Sternwood, if my mother had lived -- if I'd known a man like you before... Oh, Phil, is there ever any way back?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That depends.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (softly, intensely serious) You could help me find the way. He looks at her, saying nothing. She comes closer to him, childlike, pleading.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Phil, you've got to help me. I'm getting lost. I don't know where I'm going any more, and I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Why me, Carmen?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Because... Just because you came into the house, and I saw you. Just a little thing like that. Don't you understand, Phil? You've got something I need, some thing I've got to have. Strength, maybe. I don't know. But I've got to have it, or -- I don't know what's going to happen to me. She puts her hands on his chest, looking up into his face. For once she's completely honest.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Was that what you wanted from Shawn Regan? She draws away from him, very slowly, her eyes changing, hardening, becoming wary.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Perhaps... Phil...  164.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (gently) I'm sorry, Carmen. That's how it goes. People have to find their own way -- wherever they're going. You can, if you really want to. He turns away, to let Carmen have that moment to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Before you go... I have something that belongs to you.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (dully) what?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Your gun. I've been carrying it around, thinking I'd see you. He hands her the little gun, out of his coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Careful of it, now. It's cleaned and loaded in all five.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (taking the gun) Thanks. Marlowe moves past her, as though to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Turn around. He does so -- she has the gun leveled, and there's no dou what she's going to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Carmen!

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: It's Vivian, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: That has nothing to do...

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: It was Vivian with Shawn, too. It's always Vivian.  165. She fires point blank as Marlowe takes a step toward her continues to fire, four shots in all. Then she waits unti he has almost reached her and thrusts the pistol almost into his face. He catches her wrist just before she fires pushes her hand aside as the shot goes off. She snatches her hand free, steps back, hurls the pistol at his chest. It falls to the ground. He stoops and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So that's the way it was with Shawn.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (dazedly) But he died... why didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I blanked the shells.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (still stunned, breathless) You knew I -- You knew --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: I sort of figured it that way. And I'd like it better if Shawn had taken it in the back after all, from Eddie Mars. -- He was teaching you to shoot, wasn't he? That's what he thought he was doing. Only you didn't fire at the target.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: (with half-dreamy vindictiveness) No -- they put him in the sump -- down where the old wells are.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Couldn't you have found a cleaner place?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: He didn't mind.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. I suppose oil and water are the same as wind and air when you're dead... So Vivian paid Eddie Mars, and covered up for you.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Yes. You'd like to do something about it, wouldn't you? But you can't. I'm always safe.  166.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: How do you figure that?

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Because Vivian won't let you. And you won't do it, anyhow. You like my father, just as Shawn did. You know what would happen if you took me into court. Pictures, and long columns in the newspapers, and the Sternwood name all over the headlines. You know what that would do to father. A pause. She is looking at him like a wicked changeling.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: And Vivian's in on this, too. Way in. You wouldn't want to see her go to prison.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. I wouldn't want that. And the old man. I wouldn't want to kill him -- for you. His attitude is one of defeat. Carmen is pleased, triumphant. Marlowe turns away dejectedly, picks up his hat and coat.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (not looking at her) Better take these, Carmen, it's raining.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: Thanks. She puts them on quickly, then stands looking at Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: CARMEN
dialogues.text: I think I'm glad I didn't kill you. This is going to eat you. You're going to lie awake nights, thinking about it. And every so often you'll see me somewhere, and I'll laugh at you... Goodbye, Phil. She turns quickly toward door. Marlowe steps quickly to the light switch. As she opens the door and steps through it, he snaps off the light. There is a brief pause -- the gun fire.  188. 189. 190. 167.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Carmen crumples silently onto the doorstep. There is silence. The door swings open. Presently from the dark shrubbery Eddie Mars comes, walking slowly toward the silent shape. His gun is in his hand. He crosses the footbridge and moves the dead head with his foot. Marlowe snaps the switch inside the door; light floods suddenly out over Mars. Marlowe stands in the door, facin Mars across Carmen's body as Mars reacts.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You were a little too quick on the trigger that time, too, Eddie. His voice seems to break the spell. Mars goes for his gun starts to raise it, but Marlowe fires first. Mars drops beside Carmen. As Mars falls, the SOUND of a man running away through the garden comes OVER. Marlowe whirls, snaps a shot toward the running man, take a few quick steps, but stops as the SOUND of a car starti and roaring frantically away comes OVER. Marlowe turns toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: as he gathers up the Sternwood folder out of the box of blackmail stuff, puts it in his pocket as he turns.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: as he speaks into phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Bernie? It's me, Marlowe. I've got a couple of dead people up here at Geiger's... Yeah... Carmen Sternwood and Eddie Mars... No, I didn't shoot -- but one of them... Yeah, I hear you. And you hear me, too. I'll be at Sternwood's. I can talk just as well there. He starts to put the phone down. As he does so, Ohls' angry voice comes OVER.
