dialogues.speaker: OHLS' VOICE
dialogues.text: Marlowe -- Marlowe puts the phone down, turns to leave the booth.  191. 192. 168.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- as Norris opens the front door, admits him. Norris stares at Marlowe, divines the truth by intuition.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: It -- has happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So you knew, too, did you? But of course you did: she would have needed somebody just to keep the nightmares off. Where is she now -- Mrs. Rutledge -- As he speaks, Vivian enters. She stares at him as Norris had dome, divining the truth too.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Phil --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It's all right. I was just telling Norris. It's all all right. (Vivian sways) Catch her, Norris! Norris catches Vivian, supports her as Marlowe moves in, puts his arm around Vivian.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: We've got a few minutes until the police get here.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: In here, sir. They half carry Vivian out. INT. ALCOVE - VIVIAN, MARLOWE AND NORRIS IN B.G. Vivian has recovered control now.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Poor Carmen. Even after that -- that -- Tell me it was quick.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It was quick. She didn't even know, probably. Eddie did. He had a good half second to watch his coming.  169.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (to Vivian) She was in the darkness, and Mr. Marlowe turned the light on for her -- don't you see?

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I know. Would you really have sent her to -- to the --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes. You don't kill people for free, you know.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I know.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: So you gave Eddie Mars Shawn's fifteen thousand dollars to put him into the sump.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Only it was my fifteen thousand. I pawned the jewels mother left me. I still have Shawn's money, hoping to find his relatives -- if he had relatives. Not that it matters. I know what you must think of me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Do you? -- There's one thing bothering me. It's not the sump. Shawn wouldn't care about that now. But he was a Catholic --

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: I had prayers said for him in the Cathedral. And I brought the Father out here, too. I couldn't lie to him. He stood beside the sump and blessed Shawn. I prayed too -- for me, at least. Marlowe puts his hand under her chin, tilting her head back.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're okay, soldier. A little dumber than I am, but okay. (straightening up) I'm going to see your father now.  170.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: (rising) Yes. We must tell father --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Not we, unless you mean Norris and me. You wait here. You may have to keep Bernie Ohls from throwing me into his basement dungeon before I open my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- watching as Marlowe and Norris approach him. He, too, seems to read something by instinct.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Come, come, what's happened to my daughter now? Didn't you tell me days ago that I no longer have a heart to break?

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: It's Miss Carmen, sir --

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Yes? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: She's dead, sir. Sternwood closes his eyes, otherwise he doesn't move. Norris moves quickly and anxiously toward him, but he ope his eyes again, as black and fierce as ever.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Well? Am I to know how? Norris hesitates in dread, but Marlowe speaks smoothly.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: It was a car crash, sir. She was on her way back from Santa Barbara. It was instantaneous. I don't think she suffered at all.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: And will no more -- since it was a car crash.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: And there's one more thing. I found Shawn Regan. He's all right. Take my word for it.  194. 171. Again Sternwood's eyes shut, then open fierce and black again.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: But he will not return.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: No. He sends you his affection and respect, but he won't come back.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Norris --

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) We'll forget the pay on this. I didn't do anything. It was dropped in my lap -- They all react as Vivian enters.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIAN
dialogues.text: Phil -- they're here.

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: The police?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: What would the police be doing here, sir?

dialogues.speaker: STERNWOOD
dialogues.text: Yes. What would the police be doing here. Go to your friends, sir. I am a little tired and will ask to be excused. Goodnight, and thank you for everything.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: Goodnight, sir. He and Vivian walk away, Norris following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Marlowe, Vivian and Norris come out of the conservator Norris draws ahead, them pauses.

dialogues.speaker: NORRIS
dialogues.text: (to Marlowe) May I add my own thanks, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: You're welcome, soldier.  195. 172. Norris inclines his head, then goes off down the hall. Marlowe and Vivian give each other one of those looks, an Marlowe takes her hand, drawing her close to him. They follow Norris.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE
dialogues.text: As Marlowe and Vivian approach.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: All right, Marlowe. I'm waiting to see how you're going to talk yourself out of this one.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (laughing) For once I'm going to tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: OHLS
dialogues.text: It had better be good.

dialogues.speaker: MARLOWE
dialogues.text: (turning to Vivian) It'll be good, Bernie. It'll be very good. Because you won't have to hold me here. I've decided already myself to stay. FADE OUT.
